PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon. Sir Billy Snedden) took the chair at 2.15 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Toxic Shock Syndrome
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned by the threats to women's health and lives posed by Toxic Shock Syndrome, and urge the following steps to be taken as a matter of urgency:

(1) Tampons, sanitary napkins, vaginal deodorants and similar sanitary products to be re-classified under Therapeutic Agents (not under 'Cosmetics' as at present), in order to bring them under the scrutiny of the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee. We believe manufacture must be under the strictest hygienic conditions.

(2) After re-classification, we urge an immediate government-funded inquiry into all aspects of manufacture and content of these products. This must lead to: (i) contents of product and instructions for correct usage to be shown on packaging; (ii) removal of synthetic fibres, chemicals or ingredients that are potentially or actually harmful to users.

(3) Allocation of extra funding for ongoing research by the National Health and Medical Research Council into these products, results of this research to be made public to ensure all health workers and potential users are fully informed. This campaign of public education would necessitate multilingual distribution of the information where appropriate.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action to avert possible threats posed to women's health by implementation of the above measures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Service Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Ex-Servicemen's and Women's Pension Association is a body formed for the express purpose of obtaining a Service Pension for all Ex-Service Personnel at Sixty years of age for Men and Fifty-five years of age for Women regardless of where they served during the 1939-45 war.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should give urgent consideration to a favourable decision to the granting of the Service Pension to all Ex-Service Personnel who served their Country in time of need and who did not serve overseas through no fault of their own. The Service Pension is presently only granted to Returned Ex-Service Personnel.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Metric System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth objection to the Metric system and request the Government to restore the Imperial system.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Law Reform Commission: Privacy and Personal Information
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Paragraphs 107 and 108 of the Privacy and Personal Information discussion paper number 14, brought down by the Law Reform Commission in June 1980, undermines the family unit and the authority of parents, which is the Christian basis of our society, by proposing that 'between 12 and 16 years, a child should be entitled to object to disclosure of information to a parent'.
It is your petitioners sincere belief that:

(a) an adolescent between the ages of 12 and 16 is not at a mature enough stage of life to decide whether or not the disclosure of information to a parent will be in the best interests of the adolescent.
(b) as a record keeper has no responsibility for the child, and as his moral standards may be different to those of a parent, he should not be permitted to come between child and parent.

(c) a parent has a unique position which may enable him/her to perceive a situation that the record keeper does not. The parent must therefore be aware of the problem if remedial action is to be taken, and has the right to guide the child in the direction he/she feels fit.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
That the Members of the House of Representatives will reject the recommendation of the Law Reform Commission and find some other means to protect children from the excessive abuse of some parents.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That funding in the area of children's services, which has been reduced by almost 40 per cent in real terms over the last five years, should be restored forthwith to at least the real value of funding allocated in the 1975-76 budget. And further, that annual budget allocations in the area of children's services should be spent in full for the purposes designated.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discriminatory Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled.
The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That currently discrimination in the provision of work, in appointment to jobs and in promotion exists in Australia on particular grounds including, inter alia, grounds of race, ethnic origin, marital status, pregnancy, sex and/or sexual preferences; and
That currently discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits is exercised against particular groups of individuals-in particular, against married women.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in Commonwealth employment, in employment of individuals under federal awards, in employment of persons by statutory bodies and quasi-governmental organisations, and in employment of all persons in areas over which Commonwealth and Australian Capital Territory equal opportunity legislation should have jurisdiction; and
That appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits to all persons without regard to sex and/or marital status.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Unemployment Benefit
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully calls for:
The immediate and unconditional withdrawal of any proposals to deny Unemployment Benefits to unemployed people under 18 years old.
That the level of Benefits for all unemployed people, and including people receiving sickness benefits and pensions, be raised to at least 120 per cent of the poverty line.

That future employment policies be devoted to job creation and the restoration of full employment rather than the evasion of this responsibility by hiding the unemployed in short term training and education schemes.
Public acknowledgment of the fact that unemployment is the result of insufficient jobs and not the fault of any minority group, the education system or the unemployed themselves.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Labelling of Cosmetics
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products, and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.

That the Industries Assistance Commission, because of the Commission's terms of reference, seems unable to impose any regulation or recommend any regulation which might restrict the activities of Cosmetic Companies which produce cosmetics in which animal ingredients have been used, or for which animals were subjected to research.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will:
Legislate to require comprehensive labelling of perfumes, cosmetics and toilet preparations to indicate:
(1) whether a product contains any animal derivative. If so, the ingredient and source should be indicated.
(2) whether the research and development of that product or any of its ingredients involved experimentation on animals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Service Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth-

(1) That merchant seamen have in the past served in theatres of war; they have been decorated for valor following war action; they have been prisoners of war and should therefore be entitled to similar pension rights and medical benefits as regular servicemen.
(2) That by being denied the entitlements, such as pension and medical benefits, which other war veterans receive, they are thereby being discriminated against.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government amend the Repatriation Act (1920) Section 100 (d) (iv) to take account of war-related service by merchant seamen during World War 2.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That sandmining on Moreton Island poses a threat to the natural ecology or environment.

2. That Moreton Island is included on the interim list of the Australian Heritage Commission, and the Federal Government is urged and indeed it must, under the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975, take into consideration the protection of the island.
3. That the Queensland Government has recently renewed a further mining lease against the advice of conservationists.
Your petitioners therefore humble pray that the House will request the Government to refuse requests for export permits covering mineral sand products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Trade Unions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we are gravely disturbed by the actions of militant unions and the ACTU, the failure of the President of the ACTU to assist positively in settling the dispute which has caused massive losses to Qantas our National Airline, and we applaud the action of the Government in using RAAF planes to rescue Australians stranded abroad.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Parliament and the Government should be of firm resolve not to permit such unions to hold the country to ransom and continue to take a forceful and resolute stand against such union militancy.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telephone Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned electors of the Division of Macquarie respectfully showeth:
That we consider the lack of service provided by Telecom Australia in Sydney's 047 telephone zone is not only inconvenient, but is affecting families, business concerns and employment in the area.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government direct Telecom Australia to provide an adequate service to subscribers and users in the 047 telephone zone.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Unemployment Benefit
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the Federal Parliament in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth:
That, as concerned citizens we wish to lodge the strongest possible objection to the Government's intention to cease paying unemployment benefits to people under the age of 18 years.
We believe that this decision if carried out will:
(a) cause extreme hardship to the living standards of people under 18 years of age, especially those who do not live at home.
(b) create severe hardship on parents and families who will be forced to support people placed in this situation, and also add a further burden on community aid.
(c) Will not force the majority of young people back to school, due to lack of finance and confidence in the Education System.
(d) Cause young people to morally deteriorate by entering a life of crime, prostitution, drug abuse et cetera.
We therefore call on the Federal Government not to go ahead with this policy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF BUSINESS AND CONSUMER AFFAIRS: COMPUTER

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. Is it a fact that the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs has asked Cabinet for approval of a tender for a $12m to $14m computer? Has such approval been given? Is it a fact that discussions have been held with the Univac company about such tenders? If so, does this indicate that Univac will have the inside running to fill the tender? Further, is it a fact that the existing supplier, ICL (Aust.) Pty Ltd, has indicated that it can meet the Department's actual needs for the foreseeable future with existing equipment and at minimal cost? Finally, has the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs computer project been subject to examination by the razor gang? If so, why has it been approved? If not, why not?

—It is true that the Department is looking at the purchase of a new computer. Tenders have been called. An assessment is taking place. An announcement will be made when the Government has made a decision.
—Did the Minister for Foreign Affairs this morning call in the Soviet Ambassador? Can the Minister inform the House of the purpose of this meeting? What was the result of it?

—I did call in the Soviet Ambassador today. I drew his attention officially to the Prime Minister's statement of 6 April concerning the situation in and around Poland and the need for restraint now and in the future with a view, of course, to that statement being trans- mitted to the Soviet Government. The Ambassador, for his part, referred to the speech made by Mr Brezhnev in Prague, particularly that part of it which dealt with the capacity of Poland to find its own solutions to its problems. For all our sakes I hope that that turns out to be right. For the record, I re-emphasise what the Government has already said about the grave consequences that any form of intervention would have for the rest of the world.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Health. I refer to his answer to a question on Wednesday, 25 March, concerning prescription fees paid to chemists, who have had no effective increase since July 1977. The Minister will recall that he told the House that the Pharmacy Guild's current application for an interim increase was being assessed and that the Chairman of the Joint Committee on Pharmaceutical Benefits Pricing Arrangements, Mr Justice Ludeke, had asked for the Government's response within two weeks. As it is more than two weeks since the judge's request, can the Minister now inform the House of the Government's positive response to the Guild's application? Will the Minister also enlighten the House as to how he expects the promised new fees tribunal to undertake a full review of chemists' prescription fees by 1 July when legislation to establish that tribunal has still not even been presented to this House?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government shares the view of all those who believe that the chemists have put forward a reasonable case in applying for some increase in their remuneration. As the honourable gentleman has noted, to this end we have set out to establish a new tribunal which will give all interested parties the opportunity in public to put their cases. I think this augurs well for the future because this area has been bedevilled by misunderstandings and lack of agreement since way back in the 1960s, including all through the time when the honourable gentleman's party was in power. This is an honest attempt by the Government to resolve a difficult area.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable gentleman is quite right in saying that Mr Justice Ludeke has asked the Government to prepare and file a paper on the Guild's case by 27 April next. At present the Government is giving top priority to the development of the necessary legislation to establish the tribunal. I am very conscious of the time scales which are worrying both the honourable gentleman and members of the pharmacy profession. I can only assure him and them that the Government will do everything in its power to give all those concerned with putting their cases the opportunity to do so and to urge a speedy resolution of the problem.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I ask, firstly, whether the Government accepts that the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission properly identified the effects a shorter working week would have on the economy when it said that any reduction must be related to the productive performance of the economy as a whole and that to exceed such productivity:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . would be to build accelerating inflation into the economy, which would destroy the viability of indexation. This is not a matter of conjecture but an inescapable fact of economic life.
Secondly, what is the Government's response to the new wage fixing principles?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer to the first part of the question is, of course, yes. The Commission has unquestionably recognised that the campaign for a shorter working week was inconsistent with, and indeed represented a major threat to, the operation of an orderly system of wage determination. The Commission has clearly indicated that the shorter hours question should be tested in arbitration against the background of national economic and industrial relations priorities in the final review. The unions' attempts to selectively pressure and pick off individual industries or companies by the spurious use of so-called productivity bargaining with the intent of eventually gaining an across the board reduction in hours has unquestionably forced the Commission to point out that such action goes well beyond the spirit and the intention of its 1978 endorsement of a limited application of the productivity bargaining concept.

ANSWER.PARA: Despite the warnings by the Commission, we still heard comments yesterday and today from spokesmen of the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union stating that they were 'furious' with the decision and claiming that the new guidelines would be 'unworkable, impracticable and unrealistic'. We have heard Mr Carmichael, in particular, say to the media that the AMWSU would continue with its campaign for shorter working hours and that claims would be pursued outside the Commission. Unquestionably, these statements should stand condemned. It is the duty of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, in our view, to point out to its affiliates that expectations of shorter working hours put at risk economic recovery and maintenance and improvement of living standards as well as the survival of the wage indexation system. The commissioners made it perfectly clear that it is the survival of the system that is at stake.

The trade union officials should act responsibly and recognise that selfish claims and disruptive tactics to gain shorter hours for their members cannot be contemplated in current economic and industrial circumstances without damaging the standard of living of the Australian community. Finally, the new system of wage fixation does provide, in the Government's view, a sound basis for dealing with claims for improvements in both wages and conditions on their merits. It will be most unfortunate if those gains are jeopardised by the union movement choosing to ignore this fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Prime Minister recall suggesting in correspondence to the Premier of Tasmania that the Tasmanian Government should nominate south-west Tasmania, including the wild rivers area, for World Heritage listing? Is he aware that the Tasmanian Government has now agreed to this suggestion and will include the last wild river, the Franklin, and its catchment as part of an extended South West National Park intended for World Heritage listing? Does the Prime Minister still favour this nomination and the preservation of this unique area in its natural state?

—I am not quite sure whether the honourable gentleman asked a question only about south-west Tasmania and that wilderness area or whether impliedly he was also trying to ask a question about the damming of the Franklin, which has been a matter of some comment and notoriety in Tasmania. It is a matter on which the Government of Tasmania has taken different positions at different times. I am not quite sure what the current attitude of Mr Lowe and his Government on that issue is. I do believe that it is an issue which is largely for the Government of Tasmania. The south-western wilderness area is land of great beauty. It is unique; it is irreplaceable. I hope that it can be listed in the World Heritage list. If Mr Lowe has made the decision to seek that nomination, I think that that is a good thing. The honourable gentleman would also have noted that we have sought the listing of the Kakadu National Park as one of the great national parks of the world and of the whole area of the Great Barrier Reef as one of the marvels of the world. If the information contained in the honourable gentleman's question is correct, I am glad that the Government of Tasmania has a similar concern for that south-west wilderness area.

—I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon a congressional delegation from Mexico led by Dr Alejandro Sobarzo. On behalf of the House I extend a very warm welcome to the members of the delegation.

—I direct a question to the Treasurer. Is it the case that, in matters such as the use of direct rather than indirect taxes, the rejection of resources taxes, the control of inflation, the firm control of the money supply, a reduced role for government and tight control of government spending, the Government's policies are in line with the views of Professor Milton Friedman? Why does the Government have difficulty in agreeing with Professor Friedman's view that it is possible to introduce a taxation system that is fair and equitable and that does not discourage people from working harder and longer? Why does the Government reject the Friedman view that people who increase their incomes by working harder should not be penalised by higher tax rates and that a tax system can be devised to do away with much, if not most, of the tax evasion that goes on-most of it by the people on the highest incomes? Finally, why does the Government reject the Friedman view that government revenue would not fall under the kind of tax system he supports and that those who would benefit most from such a system would be those on the lowest incomes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true, as the preamble to the honourable gentleman's question suggests--
—Well, you wrote it.

—No, that is not true. There are a number of areas where the policies adopted by this Government and successfully pursued over the last five years are close to those advocated by Professor Friedman who is a very impressive and articulate advocate of the cause of free market forces and a person whose views have had a very significant influence on the practices of governments in the industrialised world in recent years. I refer, of course, to the importance that he places on monetary policy as an instrument to control inflation. Having said that, it does not automatically follow that, because the Government and I personally have a high regard for what the professor advocates, there is an uncritical acceptance of everything advocated, particularly in the environment in which the Australian economy operates.

ANSWER.PARA: I support very much the aspiration which is inherent in the question asked by the honourable member for Hume that we ought to strive to have a taxation system that is fair, equitable and productive of the greatest amount of incentives. I suppose that differences of opinion in the community occur as to how best one can achieve that. I believe, and the Government believes, that, if we are going to have a taxation system that significantly relies on personal income tax as a source of raising revenue, for the sake of fairness there must be some element of progressiveness in it. It should not be so great, as I pointed out in my recent parliamentary statement, as to have a significant effect on incentive. One of the things that this Government has done in that cause has been to reduce the number of steps in the tax rate scale from seven to three. This has taken out a significant part, but not all, of the progressive effect of the taxation system. I have said before, and I say again, that I regard our taxation system as being far from perfect. Equally, we have to ensure, before we embrace propositions involving radical change, that what would result from that radical change would not be more unfair and less equitable than the present system.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister will recall my question to him last Tuesday week which concerned published allegations of high level Soviet penetration of the British security organisation M16. He will recall also that in part I asked:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it a fact that there is a regular exchange of top classified security material between the British and Australian security services?

I remind the Prime Minister that he did not answer that question, and so I ask: Has he now had time to reconsider this matter and, if he has, does he hold any concern that exchanges of this sort of information over a long period could have allowed Australian classified information to fall into the hands of Soviet agents in M16? Again I ask: What steps has the Prime Minister taken on this matter? If he has done nothing to this point, will he have this aspect fully investigated so that measures can be taken to tighten this aspect of security?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition is really taking a quite extraordinary attitude, in public, to this matter. The honourable gentleman has been briefed at length by Australian security organisations. He has been briefed at length in the presence of my colleague the Minister for Defence in relation to joint facilities in Australia. He has made an extraordinary range of comments round about which makes it very difficult to ascertain his objective in relation to these matters. Earlier this week the Leader of the Opposition had-for all I know he may still have-the documents of the Hope Royal Commission into Intelligence and Security, which investigated various agencies, including the Australian Secret Intelligence Service. Therefore, he would know quite well what Mr Justice Hope thought about these matters. He would know that the view of His Honour was that ASIS should be continued and maintained.

ANSWER.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition has also had the advantage of discussions with Mr Kennison. He has sought further discussions with Mr Kennison so that he might continue his interrogation of him. That being so, I find the statement that the Leader of the Opposition made yesterday in relation to ASIS and M16-he implied that M16 had been penetrated but left open the question as to whether or not that was still the case-a quite extraordinary thing to say about an agency of a friendly government. The purpose of the honourable gentleman certainly seems to be confused; it is not one that I can detect. The honourable gentleman knows quite well that the matters that have been the subject of revelations in the United Kingdom have been dealt with at length in the parliament of that country. They occurred many years ago and involved two or three people who have been named. It is my understanding that part of the briefings of the Leader of the Opposition involved all that is known in relation to Mr Hollis and Mr Ellis. If that is not so, briefings can be reinstated in relation to them.

These matters occurred many years ago. Since then an Australian royal commission has been appointed by a Labor government. Under Mr Justice Hope it reported during the term of this Government. The recommendations, which were in relation to the totality of security organisations, have in a large way been accepted. Therefore, it would seem to make the concerns about what might have happened in an earlier period somewhat irrelevant to Australia in the 1980s. Those matters are subject to the past, and since then we have had the hearings of the royal commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —You still have not answered the question, as you didn't last week.

—I think the honourable gentleman knows full well that by the mere fact of his raising the question he is seeking to cast doubts where I believe there is no reasonable cause for doubt. I did answer the question last week. The suggestion in one newspaper article that there was a mole somewhere in the higher echelons of the Australian Public Service and that the Central Intelligence Agency or the United States Government had known of that but had not told Australia of it was too absurd to contemplate. If there had been any knowledge of that kind within the ranks of the United States I have no doubt that Australia would have been told. I have no reason to doubt the confidence that Mr Justice Hope himself exhibited in ASIS. I have no reason to doubt that whatsoever. If the honourable gentleman has any doubts, if he has any allegations to make or if he has any information to put forward, having a proper regard for considerations of the security organisations and the bipartisan approach which this Government has sought to maintain by allowing the Leader of the Opposition very full and repeated briefings on these matters, in the interests of this nation he should make those allegations to me and should not try to make public his concerns. There is a great deal wrong with raising allegations about MI6, an organisation of a friendly country, in a public way. I have no doubt that the Government of the United Kingdom would resent what the Leader of the Opposition has done in relation to that particular matter.
—So would Kim Philby.

—That, as the honourable gentleman knows, was many years ago. I am also advised that the honourable gentleman has been given advice of the debates of the House of Commons in relation to these matters, that he has been given a copy of the statement made by the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom and has been told quite plainly of the attitude of Mr Michael Foot and Sir Harold Wilson in relation to these particular matters. He knows that there have been changes in the security vetting procedures of the United Kingdom over the years since these particular circumstances arose concerning the Philby case and other cases in the United Kingdom. Circumstances in the United Kingdom are different from those of 10, 20 or 30 years ago. There is no evidence that Australian security has been prejudiced in any way. There is no evidence that Australian security has been prejudiced in any way as a result of relationships between ASIS and MI6. For the honourable gentleman to claim that in recent days there is a possibility of Australia's security being prejudiced because of that relationship is so much humbug.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. I refer to the present controversy regarding the future operations of the Industries Assistance Commission. Did the Minister see the cartoon in last Thursday's Canberra Times which depicted the future of IAC hearings as being akin to activities of a torture chamber? Is this in fact a true description of what is likely to happen in the future?

—I did see the cartoon. I was particularly impressed by the way it depicted the Minister for Industrial Relations. He was a very fetching number. I would particularly like to say that the Industries Assistance Commission is a statutory body which makes judgments on economic grounds. It is the body which advises the Government on industries which are referred to it. That advice is considered by government. I am sure that the industries have nothing to fear from a balanced judgment by government on the evidence of the IAC.

—My question which is directed to the Prime Minister follows a question asked by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition a couple of weeks ago and relates to developments in Poland and to Poland's economic circumstances. I draw the Prime Minister's attention to Press reports of Polish officials seeking food aid, loans and credits from Western European states and the United States. I ask: In view of Poland's economic need, has the Government determined an amount of assistance to Poland in food aid, loans or credits? If so, how much will be given? If not, when does it expect to make a determination? Has the Government sought to influence other Western powers to provide such economic assistance? If the Soviet Union should invade Poland, has the Government considered providing assistance to Polish refugees? Has it made contact with international organisations and governments on this matter, particularly the Swedish Government, which, according to Press reports, has been considering what action it might take in those circumstances to assist refugees? What steps have been taken by his Government to deal with organisational problems likely to occur should the need arise to assist refugees?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —An approach has been made in relation to credits, food and, I think, one or two other matters. That is currently under examination by the Government. The honourable gentleman can rest assured, especially in view of the domestic situation within Poland and the hardship being visited on the Polish people at the present time, that the Government will be looking at this request as sympathetically as possible. If a refugee situation does arise, and I think that it must be the hope of every member of this House that it will not arise, the honourable gentleman can be quite certain that Australia will be active in helping to assist refugees and in helping as many of them as we humanly can to find a home in Australia. We would want to act in a way which I think is traditional for this country. We have acted in a very forthright way in relation to refugees from Indo-China, Vietnam and Kampuchea in recent times. If the Soviet armies march into Poland and if there is a flood of refugees, the Australian organisation will be well able to assist in a very ready and forthright way. Our capacity to assist in these matters is, of course, proven and the organisation is proven. So, in a sense, special arrangements do not need to be made; the organisation is there and it is ready.

ANSWER.PARA: My colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs has had a number of discussions and a number of communications with his counterparts from overseas countries about the circumstances that could arise if there is direct Soviet intervention in Poland. The maximum degree of co-operation, not only in the appropriate reactions to the Soviet Union itself but especially in assistance to refugees, is something which many countries would have at the forefront of their policies. Again, it should be the objective of all members of this House to make sure, to the extent that we can, that that situation does not arise and that there is continuation of the degree of restraint of which I spoke in my statement a couple of days ago and which the Soviet Union has shown so far-for reasons which only the Soviet Union can give-compared to the nature of its actions in Afghanistan or earlier in Czechoslovakia or Hungary. I hope it is the objective of all nations to make sure that the Soviet Union understands that it is not only in its own interests but also in the interests of the widest international community that it should not act and move its troops against Poland.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Prime Minister inform the House what mechanism the Government intends to use to allow all Australians to share in the mineral boom?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman would know very well that, as a result of mining and mineral developments, a great deal of direct employment is provided. He would also know that, in addition to that, many service industries need to be established on site or in the town or place of development and that many other Australian firms are able to expand their employment because they gain contracts for fabricating works and the provision of the supplies and services which are needed as a result of major resource development. Of course, State governments gain considerable revenue as a result of mining ventures. Some governments in particular, by various devices, gain very significant additions to their normal revenues and that, of course, is used as they think fit for the benefit of all the people in their States.

ANSWER.PARA: Taking the major mining corporations overall, I am advised-subject to correction by my colleagues-that approaching 60 per cent of the profits of the major companies is involved in either Commonwealth or State taxation. If that figure is correct, 60c out of every $1 is a very substantial return for the treasuries of the States or the Commonwealth-moneys which, of course, are used to help to provide the services, the standard of living, the maintenance of welfare payments, and the improvement of assistance for the disabled which are so necessary in a compassionate and concerned community. So the revenues that governments, both State and Federal, gain from these ventures under present arrangements are very considerable indeed. It ought also to be noted that a small number of projects would seem to gain the public eye because they turn out to be, in a sense, highly profitable. They attract a great deal of attention and often notoriety. But, especially in oil exploration, there are many companies and many ventures which result in no economic return at all. The stimulus to enable that venture to take place is not only the implementation of appropriate Government policies but also the possibility of significant reward, having in mind the fact that the chances of success are not necessarily high and therefore the prospect of high returns has to be in place or the drilling and expansion of exploration just would not take place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Industry and Commerce aware of a statement made on Monday of this week by the Executive General Manager of Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd steel division that because of unfair competition from heavily subsidised steel imports it will be necessary to redeploy approximately 60 to 80 employees at the company's Newcastle works, 200 at Port Kembla and approximately 60 to 80 at Whyalla? Is it correct that last year 200,000 tonnes of steel plates and 100,000 tonnes of steel tubes were imported? Have these imports been heavily subsidised by overseas countries? Is the Australian steel industry protected by a tariff rate of only 8 per cent compared with rates of up to 40 per cent and 50 per cent by some countries, as well as other forms of assistance, such as accelerated depreciation of capital equipment? Finally, is it correct that the Industries Assistance Commission has been investigating the Australian steel industry for the past seven years? If so, when can we expect a decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lynch The Rt Hon Sir P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I anticipate that a joint statement by myself and the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs will be issued on the Industries Assistance Commission report during the next 48 hours. I understand from the Press reports, to which the honourable gentleman has referred, that the jobs of some 400 Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd workers will be affected by cutbacks at various of the company's operations. My understanding is that there will not be any retrenchment but that the employees, given the traditional approach by the corporation to the problems it is obviously suffering at the present time, will be redeployed in other areas and on other purposes. I am sure that all honourable members of the House are very much aware of the very depressed nature of the world steel industry with the excess capacity that that provides throughout the world and the problems which a number of markets, including Australia, are experiencing at present. I assure the honourable gentleman that both I and my colleague, together with officials from our various departments, are watching the question of steel imports to make a judgment as to whether overseas firms are seeking to move some of that surplus production on to the Australian market. It is certainly true that recent import order statistics for some steel products have been subjected to an upward movement and the translation of these order figures into actual imports will be the subject of very close monitoring indeed. The House will be aware of the mechanisms which are employed both in the European Economic Community and in the United States of America at present to protect their industries against dumping. I assure the honourable gentleman and the House that the Government would not wish or allow Australia to become a dumping ground for overseas surplus steel production. Discussions are already taking place between the departments of Industry and Commerce and Business and Consumer Affairs, and the Government's response to the recent Industries Assistance Commission report on steel will be subject to announcement perhaps today or, at the latest, by tomorrow.

—Is the Minister for Transport aware of the very real problems of isolation and inadequate transport for the many thousands of Australians living in the Northern Territory, north Queensland and the north-west of Western Australia? Does he recall that many of the roads in northern Australia are poor at the best of times but quite impassable during the wet season? Does he recognise that adequate air services in northern Australia are essential for the carriage of passengers and freight and services such as mail and newspapers, which may be taken for granted in the rest of Australia? Will the Minister compensate these areas for the very real disabilities by subsidising from Government revenue northern Australian airlines to the extent of at least twice the amount that he has recommended for Tasmania, particularly in view of the proportion of the gross national product that is generated in northern Australia?

—The answer to the first question is yes. The answer to the second question is yes. The third question asked by the honourable member relates to policy. However, I advise him and the House that there are already in place a number of subsidy programs that do assist airlines in the delivery of mail and other supplies to some of the outlying areas of north Queensland, the Northern Territory and Western Australia. The reason the Government decided to compensate the Tasmanians was that they, of course, do not have a land bridge. The northern parts of Australia have a land bridge, although it be a somewhat bumpy bridge. However, if the honourable gentleman wishes to pursue this matter on behalf of the people of the northern part of Australia, we would be very pleased to have some discussions with him.

—I preface my question to the Minister for Communications by saying that I feel sure the Minister is aware of the importance of the telegram service because of its familiarity and its accessibility to members of the public and to business. Will the Minister take action to arrest the decline in the quality and usage of the telegram service as compared with the public telex? Why can he not require Telecom Australia, with its considerable financial resources, to maintain and improve its telegram service at price levels which people can afford to pay?

—I think that on this subject many of us have a good deal of sympathy with the sentiments expressed in the honourable gentleman's question. I was a little amazed when I took over the portfolio to find how the frequency of telegram usage had in fact slipped.
—They cannot pay.

—It has gone down from something like 19 million a year only a few years ago to about 5 million last year. As the honourable gentleman has said, the cost of providing the service is regrettably so high that it serves as a real deterrent to most people when they look at alternative ways of communicating a message. It is certainly true that it is a labour intensive service. A number of honourable members, including the honourable member for Fadden, put a proposition a little while ago that appealed to me-that is, providing a few set text messages capable of being sent with minimal human involvement and consequently at a reduced charge. To date I have not been able to persuade Telecom as to the wisdom of either that step or any other. But I will certainly draw the honourable member's question to its attention. I will suggest that there are many members of this place and people around Australia generally who look to the maintenance of an effective, efficient and economic telegram service as part of the continued communications requirements of this community.

—My question, which I direct to the Minister for Housing and Construction, concerns the role of the Department of Housing and Construction in recognising 1981 as the International Year of Disabled Persons. What action has his Department taken across Australia to improve access to Commonwealth buildings and what further action is to be initiated?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The main activity of the Department of Housing and Construction as part of the Government's combined effort in the International Year of Disabled Persons has been to carry out a survey of the 500 buildings the Commonwealth owns or leases in various areas of Australia. That survey commenced in November and is planned to finish at the end of this month. There are two things we have to look at-not only the way in which to get disabled people into a building but also the way in which they can go about their business once they get into a building. We have found that the most desirable things to put into buildings are access ramps, sliding doors and the toilets necessary for disabled people. It is desirable also to lower the height of counters and telephones.

ANSWER.PARA: Following the announcement by my colleague, the Minister for Administrative Services, that the Government has allocated the sum of $250,000 this year to be spent by the end of June, the Department has recommended to me a list of 27 places in Australia where work is required to be carried out. In the next couple of weeks I will be writing to the members in the electorates where those 27 places are situated, indicating to them the type of work which is required. The work will be done by the end of June. It is hoped that the activities of the Government and of the various departments will act as a catalyst to encourage private enterprise to get on with the task of making buildings accessible to the disabled.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Health whether he is aware that under the present health insurance arrangements some 22 per cent of pensioners with pensioner health benefit entitlements also hold private hospital and/or medical insurance. Is he further aware that this involves unnecessary hospital and medical insurance contributions of $10m to $20m a year by Australian pensioners? Will the Minister guarantee that any future system this Government introduces will end its current practice of ripping off millions of dollars a year from Australian pensioners simply because of the confusion created by some nine changes made to the health insurance system by this Government in its four years of office?

—One of the characteristics of a government of our persuasion is that it tries to maximise the people's choice. If people wish to take out health insurance I believe it is their right so to do. If pensioners wish to take out health insurance, for whatever reason, they should be allowed to continue to do so.
—I ask the Minister for Communications: Is it a fact that as of today certain people living in inland Australia will be able to receive a continuous television signal from Intelsat IV?

—I know that the honourable gentleman, like his predecessor in the seat of Maranoa, has been most concerned that the far-flung distances between the centres and the people he represents have inconvenienced them as far as communications generally are concerned. I am delighted to be able to advise him that at Birdsville and Bedourie television reception is now possible as a result of a signal sent through Intelsat IV. It is part of the Commonwealth's program to provide television communications to people in remote areas of Australia. A number of other centres in the electorate of Maranoa and, indeed in other remote areas of Australia, are to be included in a similar way as funds, time and work permit. It certainly is a system which will bring new access for those who live in those remote areas. The system involves the transmission of Australian Broadcasting Commission programs from Sydney to those two outback centres. I trust that they receive the signal well and welcome the new reception available to them.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Health, follows his response to the question asked by the honourable member for Ballarat in which he sought to embellish the principle of choice as being an option available to pensioners in relation to health insurance. I refer the Minister to the Auditor-General's report for 1981 which states, in relation to the Department of Health, that approximately 16 per cent-only 16 per cent-of medical practitioners in New South Wales accept the Commonwealth benefit as full payment for medical expenses of eligible pensioners. I ask the Minister: Whilst acknowledging that this is consistent with the Health Insurance Act, does the Government approve of members of the wealthy medical profession compelling pensioners to pay up to $5 out of their own pocket for every doctor contact that they have to make? I ask further: Does the Minister recognise that this situation will force some pensioners who are eligible for free government cover to take out expensive private health insurance as well? Finally, does the Minister agree that this is not in the interests of cost containment within our health care system but is an additional cost generated by the medical profession? What does he propose to do about it in order to protect the interests and welfare of dependent pensioners?

—There seems to have been an attitude, consistently expressed by the Leader of the Opposition both during his present incumbency and while he was a Minister in the Labor Government, aimed at denigrating the medical profession. This consistent attitude, which has been displayed by him and by his party, has sought to portray the medical profession as comprising rapacious individuals who seek nothing but their own financial rewards. The fact is that the vast majority of the medical profession of this country have provided over the years a highly efficient medical service to the people of Australia and, in a great many instances, have provided services free of charge to people in necessitous circumstances. The fact is that the range of medical services available to the people of Australia is of a very high standard indeed. The various options available to people, whether or not they take out health insurance, mean that in a very real sense a choice is available to them. For sure, there are occasions when people in necessitous circumstances have been required by medical practitioners to make some contribution to the cost of the services provided. That is up to the individual medical practitioner. But I say again that, overall, the medical service that is provided by professionals in this country is of a very high standard indeed. I do not think it is advantaged by continually being denigrated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented.
—If the honourable gentleman wishes to make a personal explanation, he may proceed.

—In the course of Question Time the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), in responding to a question that I asked of him in relation to security matters, sought to impute my motivation and, it would seem, to imply that there was something sinister involved, although he was not precise in identifying what it was. I want to make clear that in relation to those matters which quite properly are confidential and secret there will be no disclosure by me. My record in that respect is consistent, but we must make a distinction between an obsession with security for security's sake, to the point at which it impairs a proper awareness within the community of certain functions about which the public should be informed, and that level of confidentiality which must be preserved in the national interest. I remind you, Mr Speaker, of processes in other countries, such as the United States of America, where a relatively open inquiry system is associated with the congressional system of government. If, finally, I can establish beyond any doubt this obsessiveness which infects the Government--
—Order! I cannot allow the honourable gentleman to debate the matter. He is entitled to make a personal explanation which states the misrepresentation, and the true position.

—In relation to the personal misrepresentation suffered in this matter, I want to add that a few nights ago I received a very large envelope from the Prime Minister's office; it was addressed to me. I opened it and found inside another envelope addressed to me. The top left-hand corner and the bottom right-hand corner were stamped 'Personal To Be Opened By Addressee Only'. It was also stamped 'CONFIDENTIAL' on top and bottom. On the back were similar confidential stamps, with a direction about being opened only by the addressee. There were five security stickers from the Prime Minister's Department. Of course, one is always enthralled at the exciting prospect that one is going to share some of the top secrets of the nation; so, with trembling hands, I opened the envelope. I found the following communication:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hayden:
SIR ROGER HOLLIS
You asked for a copy of the statement by Mrs Thatcher, made in the House of Commons on 26 March 1981.
Oh, but there is a reason. There has to be double security as the communication stated:
Two copies are attached.
The communication continued:
You also asked if the Leader of the Opposition in the Commons had commented on the statement. I noted that Mrs Thatcher had consulted with Mr Foot--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. This is not a personal explanation within the rules. The honourable member is making a speech which does not come within any ruling that you have given, Mr Speaker. It does not come within the Standing Orders. I ask that you direct the Leader of the Opposition to resume his seat.

—The honourable gentleman is entitled to state a misrepresentation and state the facts. The honourable gentleman has now reached the boundaries of stating the facts. I ask him to proceed but to remain within my ruling.
—I conclude by quoting the following comment from the letter:

SPEECH.PARA: The attached copy of an extract from 'The Times' shows that Mr Foot did question Mrs. Thatcher on her statement.
So, we have it in a nutshell: The security of the nation depends on the latest edition of the London Times.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I certainly do.
—How could he be?
—Mr Speaker, could I have a bit of order from these gentlemen, please?
—I call the honourable member for Franklin.

—Two members of the Australian Labor Party, the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Armitage) and the honourable member for Henty (Mrs Child), yesterday in this place misrepresented remarks which I had made about the role of women in the family. As a result, a newspaper, the Hobart Mercury, carried a story which is unfair to my position.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members-Ha, ha.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Franklin will resume his seat. I remind honourable members on my left that the time may come when they wish to make a personal explanation. They will expect to be heard in silence. I ask them to listen in silence to the personal explanation which is being made.

—The honourable members for Chifley and Henty claimed that I downgraded women and that I deliberately wanted to see less money spent on child care centres. Any fair reading of what I said would not lead to that interpretation. What I said quite simply was that lower taxes would allow more women a free choice, and that choice includes the right, if they wish, to remain at home and to look after their families. Many women want to do that. On page 1400 of Hansard of 7 April 1981, I said:

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that the Government will move . . . towards the aim of reducing taxation . . . Then we might not need to direct some of the money that is directed at child welfare clinics, other clinics and so forth. If we can do that, the fabric of the family will be stronger and Australia will be a better place to live in.

There is nothing in those remarks which downgrades women. I ask for an apology from the honourable member for Chifley and the honourable member for Henty. I ask the Mercury to reprint accurately my remarks which I made in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present the Australia-China Council second annual report for the year ended 30 June 1980. I seek leave to make a short statement on the activities of the Council.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is firmly committed to the continued development of a broader and mutually beneficial bilateral relationship with China. During the 12 months covered by this report, Australian contacts with China expanded rapidly. Personally, I was pleased to have the opportunity to visit China in January this year. Chinese Vice-Premier Li Xiannian, the most senior Chinese leader ever to visit Australia, was here in May 1980. During that visit, an agreement on co-operation in science and technology was signed. It was also agreed to begin negotiation of a cultural agreement to establish a technical co-operation program and to encourage further exchanges in the social sciences.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australia-China Council has an important role to play in this process. Since it was established in June 1979 the Council has established policy guidelines for its work, and set up programs and advisory panels in areas such as academic and educational matters, science and technology, culture and the arts, social science, publications, and sport and community affairs. The Council has emphasised its role as a catalyst, bringing interest groups in Australia and China together, rather than involving itself directly in arrangements for exchanges. At the end of its first year of operations the Council was pleased to report that the circle of those involved in exchanges with China of various kinds had widened greatly. In the past nine months the Council has continued to promote exchanges with China. It has also sought to increase awareness in the community of the longer term advantages of increased communication and exchanges between Australia and China. The Council has maintained its emphasis on keeping people informed of its work. A party of six journalists from metropolitan and regional newspapers in five States toured China for three weeks, and the Council has supported the development of relations between the Melbourne Age and the Peking People's Daily, leading to the production of an English-language daily paper in Peking which is shortly to begin.

Some new areas of Council activity include continuing negotiations for a group of Aboriginal health workers to visit China to observe the 'barefoot doctor' arrangements and other Chinese community health services; financial support to the Museums Association of Australia to host a visit to Australia by a group of senior Chinese museums staff; preparations for a return visit by an Australian women's delegation to China, to reciprocate the visit by a Chinese women's delegation mentioned in this report; and the exchange with China of delegations of publishers, and discussions on copyright matters. In association with the International Cultural Corporation of Australia and the major sponsor, Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, the Council contributed towards the Chinese classical paintings exhibition which opened in Sydney on 31 March. These are only several examples of the wide and increasing range of contacts between Australia and China which have been developed and are continuing to be made by the Australia-China Council. I have much pleasure in tabling the second annual report of the Australia-China Council for 1979-80.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-The Opposition is pleased that the Government is pursuing contacts which the Labor Government initiated with the People's Republic of China. It is important to this nation and to our ability to conduct a principled, independent and coherent foreign policy that we develop and maintain a mature relationship with each of the major powers.
—What about Billy McMahon?

—I do not know what the honourable member means. The point I am trying to convey to the House is that we established the relationship there because of what we felt was a mature situation which I am now congratulating the Government for continuing. I had the opportunity to lead the first parliamentary delegation to China in June 1973. I welcomed the support I received from the late Senator Ivor Greenwood and others. It is of interest to note that that initiative was taken by the Labor Government.

SPEECH.PARA: We must foster increased awareness of our respective cultures and be prepared to allocate adequate finances to programs which will increase understanding. In particular, we should be encouraging our young people in this regard. I applaud the activities of the Australia-China Council in that regard. It was a significant step forward when we signed the agreement of co-operation in science and technology. I also note from the report and from the statement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) that the respective governments have agreed to begin the negotiation of a cultural agreement. There is some suggestion and an uneasy feeling that the latter agreement is being impeded by cuts in the staff of the Department of Foreign Affairs. I hope that this is not the case. I would welcome the assurance of the Minister to that effect. I believe that it is important that we move ahead with it.
There is one particularly disturbing aspect of the report and it relates to developments which have occurred, since its publication, with respect to Radio Australia. The Council stated:

In possibly the most dramatic development, Radio Australia opened postal boxes in Hong Kong and Beijing and in twelve months from January 1979 received over 100,000 letters from those who hear its Chinese-language broadcasts.

The response from Chinese listeners is set out in detail in the section of the report dealing with the media and information program. It was a great response and an encouraging reaction but the question is, what was the Government's response. Apparently it has been an extraordinarily shortsighted and miserly one. It did not renew funds available to Radio Australia and ten translators employed to deal with the correspondence have been sacked.

I do not question the integrity, ability and hard work of the members of the Council; but I think it is important that the Government give them support. It is unfair that their actions have been undermined by the decisions to which I have just referred. The Minister said:
The Government is firmly committed to the continued development of a broader and mutually beneficial bilateral relationship with China.

If this is the case, the Government should ensure the decision to which I have just referred is reversed and that no similar decisions are taken in the future. The urgency of the matter is highlighted by the fact that letters reaching Radio Australia now run at the rate of 200,000 a year.

It is obvious that China is of immense importance to our region, and its importance is growing. I believe the other power in this region whose importance is growing is Australia. This presents us with important opportunities. The time available only allows me to make the general point: That our own activity in this area should be substantially increased. I hope that can be done.

I applaud the great progress that has been made by the Chinese in overcoming the problems of their nation, including their outstanding efforts to improve living conditions for all people within their society and to modernise to achieve that result. However, I also point out that the Australian Labor Party remains strongly committed to the view that the best interests of all people are served by a democratic government and the right of citizens to organise free trade unions to promote their interests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present a report of the Australian Bureau of Animal Health on the sea transport of sheep. I seek leave to make a statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have said on several occasions in the past that the Commonwealth supports the continuation of the live sheep export trade, providing it is carried out under the best animal welfare conditions. That is still the case. To ensure that these conditions are maintained and improved where necessary, the Government has continued to monitor the live sheep export trade and, indeed, other livestock exports. Government veterinarians accompanied a shipment of live horses for slaughter to Japan in May last year, a shipment of sheep to the Middle East in September-October last year, and a shipment of cattle to Indonesia in January this year. A veterinarian is currently accompanying another live sheep ship en route to the Middle East.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of this continuing assessment of the livestock export trades, the Government is able to keep abreast of developments and changing needs. The report I have just tabled, by the Australian Bureau of Animal Health, deals specifically with the live sheep export trade. This trade has grown quite dramatically over recent years. In 1971-72, just under one million head of sheep were exported for slaughter. By 1979-80, that figure had grown to over five and a half million head, and this financial year live sheep exports for slaughter are expected to exceed six million head. The trade is worth over $124m in foreign earnings, and is therefore an important industry. Obviously, any trade that grows as quickly and extensively as has the live sheep export trade, must be expected to encounter some problems. This report by the BAH into the sea transport of sheep has pointed to a number of deficiencies which need to be rectified. The Government has accepted the conclusions and recommendations of the Bureau and I have already set in train a number of a measures which will further improve the conditions under which live sheep are exported from Australia. I am determined to ensure that all requirements for this trade are met. If they are not, then shippers will face the prospect of not being allowed to load, or of having to sail with a reduced cargo.

Several of the deficiencies noted by the Bureau's report should not, in fact, have been occurring. They are matters which are covered by existing standards and regulations, and therefore a greater policing of the requirements of the trade will in itself bring about considerable improvements. The Commonwealth has the constitutional responsibility for animal exports. The Bureau of Animal Health co-ordinates and supervises this activity by delegating inspection and certification functions to State departments of agriculture. Accordingly, with respect to the specific deficiencies mentioned in the Bureau's report, the following measures are being adopted to improve welfare aspects of the live sheep export trade. I will briefly paraphrase each deficiency, as found by the report, and outline the action that is being taken in each case.
Unsuitable sheep are presented for export:
To overcome this the Bureau has told State authorities that sheep at farms or assembly points must be inspected wherever possible to ensure that unsuitable sheep do not enter the export process.
Inadequately prepared-preconditioned-sheep are presented for export:
The standards spell out requirements for preconditioning and these must be observed. If not, sheep will be rejected by the State officers carrying out the inspections at assembly points.
Sheep off-shears are being presented for export:

The standards require that sheep not be shipped within 14 days of shearing. Unsatisfactory wool length will lead to rejection of sheep by State officers carrying out the inspections at assembly points.
Sheep with excessive wool length are being presented for export:

The standards require that average wool length should not be more than 25 millimetres. This will be insisted on by final certifying officers. Sheep with wool length in excess of 25 millimetres will not be passed for loading.
As culling takes place in the pre-export process mobs are 'topped up' at short notice with unsuitable sheep:
This will not be permitted. If suitable sheep are not on hand to make up numbers, ships will sail with reduced numbers. Certifying officers at shipside will ensure this.
Some yards and feedlots are poorly designed and maintained:

Yards and feedlots will be regularly inspected by State officers. Improvements and maintenance must be carried out as required and sheep will not be allowed to be handled through substandard facilities.
Unskilled people are handling sheep:

Shippers are required to employ only skilled personnel for sheep handling. If State officers find cases where skilled personnel are not on hand, then loading will not take place until such employees are provided by the shippers.
Junior officers supervise shipments of sheep.
State departments of agriculture have been asked to locate senior and experienced officers at shipside during loading to ensure proper handling practices are observed.
Although it may be only a short haul from assembly point to shipside, some sheep are distressed by poor transportation:

All facilities and transports used to move sheep from assembly points to shipside will be inspected by State officers, prior to any transportation. Unsuitable or deficient vehicles will not be allowed to transport sheep and State inspectors will ensure that no overcrowding takes place during transportation.
Sheep are being loaded in mixed lots causing bullying and overcrowding:
The drafting of sheep of different sexes, ages and weights will be better supervised by State officers. Indiscriminate mixing will not be allowed.
Ship maintenance is sometimes delayed resulting in poor facilities on board:

Inspections are to be made of every live sheep ship as it docks, and where necessary repairs carried out before sheep are loaded. These inspections are normally made by Department of Transport officers examining the ship for safe practice. In future State departments of agriculture officers will also carry out inspections relating to the husbandry needs of sheep. Repairs are the responsibility of the shipping companies. If repairs cannot be made at once ships will not be allowed to load sheep to full complement.
Feed provided on shipboard is sometimes of low quality and palatablity:

A new BAH instruction requires that feed must be of adequate quality and palatability. Feed is to be inspected on each ship. If it is found to be inadequate for any reason, ships will not be permitted to load sheep until deficiencies are corrected.
Watering facilities may be inadequate or poorly maintained:
The Department of Transport will require improvement to unsatisfactory watering facilities.
Unsatisfactory distribution of sheep occurs on some ships:

State inspecting officers are to ensure that sheep are distributed as comfortably as possible throughout each ship to ensure overcrowding does not occur. This requirement will be rigidly enforced even if it means that a ship does not take on its full intended load.
Problems with ventilation:
Ventilation systems are to be inspected before loading of each ship and numbers to be shipped on the vessel will be reduced if necessary.
The special nature of sheep husbandry on board ship must be clearly recognised:

There is a need for specific research related to the shipboard environment. The Australian Bureau of Animal Health has set in train studies to initiate and co-ordinate research into the specific needs of sheep transported at sea, as suggested in recommendation 3 of the report. The study will be ongoing, and will involve consultation with State departments of agriculture, the sheep and transport industries and welfare organisations. If further improvements are determined by this research, they will be incorporated progressively into the export process.

The measures I have outlined will further enhance the animal welfare and husbandry requirements of this industry. The Government will continue to monitor the trade, and will in particular closely police the standards and regulations to ensure that all requirements are being met. I have advised State governments, and through them, exporters, of these new requirements. Furthermore, I am proposing to hold a meeting shortly with all concerned with the live sheep export trade to emphasise the Commonwealth's determination that husbandry conditions be maintained and improved wherever necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This is almost a tongue twister statement, but it is a very important matter. The final mortality on this shipment was 1.5 per cent.

. . . true mortality figures are difficult to establish for such shipments because of the logistics of obtaining an accurate on/off count uncomplicated by other factors.

On the morning of day 4 . . . an electrical fault caused a breakdown in ventilation and higher mortalities subsequently occurred in sheep on closed decks on days 4 and 5. This strongly suggests that the differences in mortality between sheep on open and closed decks can be partly attributed to differences in ventilation.
In terms of morbidity, the report states:

The report continues with veterinary information on the conditions of the sheep, including post-mortem findings. I will summarise the situation by saying that one cannot accurately determine the exact situation with respect to morbidity because of poor lighting and high stocking densities. Let us look at the 300 sheep that were examined by post-mortem. A total of 86 per cent of those sheep showed hyperacute or acute lung lesions. It is very obvious that one of the major factors in design of the sheep ships relates to the ventilation conditions. The Department of Transport has already laid down certain conditions. I welcome the fact that the BAH has now said, in its general conclusion, that there is a need for a lot more research into the conditions on ship. The report states:

It then outlines a program of research and development. I hope that the Minister is fair dinkum when he says that he will see that this happens. The report makes sensible, professional and general recommendations. It is good to see that the Minister has pulled out from the report the very specific areas of concern and has informed the House of the actions that are now to be taken. Unless we see the original report, it is difficult to say where most attention should be directed.
