One can validly hypothesise, without seeing the other report, that the strongest criticism in the report must have related to conditions on the ships. This is the area in which the recommendations of this report I believe are the weakest. By way of summary the report states:

All who are working in this industry and wish to make sure that it continues to flourish in its own interests, and in the interests of the Australian sheep industry and rural Australia, must also work at all levels to see that there are no departures from good husbandry practices in the transport of sheep.

We all agree to that. The Opposition wants to see a live sheep trade that is best for the farmers, best for the meat workers and best for the sheep. We need full information on all aspects of this trade. If, as appears to be the case, a more detailed report is available, we would like to see it. As it is, the Minister has said that another veterinarian is accompanying another ship; perhaps we will get more information as a result of that. The Opposition intends to see that the veterinarian ensures the State authorities carry out what they should have been carrying out all along and that the procedures will be tightened up.

I will say a few words on the live sheep trade itself. This is very much a volatile issue. We have had a lot of experience in this matter. It is a matter which concerns the Australian Meat Industry Employees Union because it sees the live sheep trade threatening the income of its members. At the same time, the live sheep trade must be said to be good for the farmers because normally, at this stage into a drought, the price of live sheep in this country would be at very depressed levels; but the price has held up. This is partially due to the fact that many live sheep have been shipped out at high rates. The flock structure itself-a little research has been done on this-is adjusting to the new demand. It is actually in a healthy condition. There is a higher percentage of ewes than there was previously. The average age of the flock is younger. These things will benefit the basic breeder stock for the future sheep industry, whether it be meat or wool. If there had not been a drought the sheep flock would have been larger by this time. On the latest figures the killing rates for sheep have increased locally. Again, the impact of the drought has distorted the figure. A drought can have the effect of activating the number of sheep being killed and it is difficult to get a long term trend and to show accurately what is happening. That is one of the biggest problems of working with figures in the whole livestock area.

One of the things we have to stress in considering the whole question of live sheep exports and the slaughtering industry is that the industry structure at the abattoir level is bad. There has been over-investment and a number of other problems. If we are to solve those problems and those of the unions we should look at the slaughtering industry and the processing industry as a whole. The slaughtering industry causes the problem as much as the export of live sheep does. We have to work out what changes are occurring in the whole industry. Are the changes in the sheep and lamb sections of the meat industry signifiantly different? To what extent are the same factors prompting change in different components of the industry? I can answer those questions myself to some degree. I believe that all parts of the industry are declining and need restructuring. Essentially the same set of factors are operating. The drought is accentuating the problem of the whole slaughtering and processing industry.

A report on the live sheep trade was prepared by Mr Miller of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. Again, this report has not seen the light of day but I have heard somewhere on the grapevine that we may yet see it. If that report sees the light of day I hope that the figures in it will be updated and relevant to today's situation. The live sheep industry will always present a problem in the industrial relations area. The sanest people need to discuss the problem rationally. While many animals are being exported live, there is no way that unionists in the abattoirs will be convinced that that is not denying them some income. If we are to solve this problem we have to look at the slaughtering industry overall and find out the reasons why the Middle East countries cannot engage in the chilled meat trade a little more.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MACPHEE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On 26 February the honourable member for Casey (Mr Falconer) drew the attention of the House to Press reports of interviews with Miss Liliana Gasinskaya in which it was claimed that she had retained her Soviet citizenship and her Soviet passport to travel overseas last year and had visited her parents in the Soviet Union. Bearing in mind Miss Gasinskaya's claims in 1979 when she was granted refugee status on the recommendation of the Determination of Refugee Status Committee that she held a well-founded fear of persecution should she return to her homeland, I instructed the Chairman of the DORS Committee to make inquiries into the reported statements in the Press and elsewhere.

SPEECH.PARA: Following this, officials conducted an extensive inquiry into Miss Gasinskaya's activities over the last year. Miss Gasinskaya was subsequently interviewed on two occasions. During these interviews marked inconsistencies in her various accounts of her overseas visits emerged.

Despite these inconsistencies, my Department was able to establish beyond reasonable doubt that at no stage had she visited the Soviet Union and that she had not used a Soviet travel document for a visit to Britain last year. Miss Gasinskaya travelled to the United Kingdom and returned using a certificate of identity issued by the Department of Foreign Affairs for use by non-citizens when they travel abroad. In the first interview Miss Gasinskaya claimed that she had not returned to the Soviet Union but that she had visited her mother in London. In the second interview she admitted that she has not seen her mother since she arrived in a Soviet vessel in Sydney over two years ago. Independent checks by my Department have confirmed this. Having examined all the evidence, the DORS Committee has advised me as follows:
The Committee is of the view that, on the evidence available, there are insufficient grounds for revocation of Liliana Gasinskaya's refugee status.

However, during these interviews Miss Gasinskaya admitted that she had applied to the Soviet authorities for the return of her Soviet citizenship and the issue of an appropriate travel document valid for travel to the Soviet Union and return. I am informed that, in so doing she sought certain assurances from the Soviet authorities. In making these applications Miss Gasinskaya was no doubt motivated by an understandable desire to see her family again. Her applications however raise new issues, the significance of which Miss Gasinskaya does not appear to comprehend. If her application were to be granted by the Soviet Authorities so that she again became a citizen of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, Article 1C of the 1951 Geneva Convention on the Status of Refugees would apply. It states:
This Convention shall cease to apply to any person falling under the terms of Section A if:
(1) He has voluntarily re-availed himself of the protection of the country of his nationality; or
(2) Having lost his nationality, he has voluntarily reacquired it . . .

For this reason, the Committee has advised me that it 'is of the view that the question of Miss Gasinskaya's refugee status should be kept under review. Miss Gasinskaya should be counselled about the seriousness of her situation and the possible results of any such action.'

It is difficult to explain Miss Gasinskaya's actions throughout the investigation and the motives that might lie behind them. The inconsistencies in her various statements have caused me great concern and have led me to scrutinise all of these inconsistencies most carefully.

Having done so, I have come to the same conclusion as the DORS Committee, namely that she has not breached the Convention under which she was granted refugee status despite the fact that even the kindest critic of her public utterances would regard her conduct as disturbing and extraordinary for a refugee. I have instructed the Chairman of the DORS Committee that she should be counselled about her situation and the prospect that, should she proceed with her application to reacquire Soviet citizenship, she would come within the terms of Article 1C (2) of the Geneva Convention and would lose her refugee status.

The question of her resident status in Australia is a separate matter. Miss Gasinskaya was granted permanent residence by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs soon after being granted refugee status by my predecessor. She left Australia in June last year. Whilst she was given a return endorsement prior to her departure, she did not receive a new entry permit granting either permanent or temporary residence when she re-entered Australia in August. At that point her previous entry permit which afforded her permanent residence in Australia expired in accordance with the provisions of the Migration Act. I am informed by my Department that this was due to an oversight by a Commonwealth Officer on the primary line.

To regularise Miss Gasinskaya's status I have decided that she should be given a temporary entry permit, with permission to work, for a period of six months. This will enable her to consider her position and be counselled by my Department about the consequences of her actions. If she proceeds with her application to the Soviet authorities she will do so in the full knowledge of what that means in terms of her refugee and resident status. If she withdraws her applications or should they be refused by the Soviet authorities I would be prepared to consider an application from her for the restoration of her permanent residency.
Miss Gasinskaya is being informed of my decision and has been advised to keep the Regional Director of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in Sydney informed of her intentions.

The granting of refugee status is a most important act. Those granted refugee status have rights and privileges bestowed by the international convention and protocol relating to the status of refugees which Australia has ratified. It is important that refugee status should be given only to those who meet the definition in the convention and that refugee status is not abused. As I have indicated, the DORS Committee advised me that Miss Gasinskaya has not taken any action which would justify removing her refugee status but she has taken action which could lead to a course of events which would involve her losing refugee status.

I believe that as this matter was raised in Parliament it is appropriate that I should respond in Parliament. The delay in making this response reflects the conflicting nature of assertions made by Miss Gasinskaya and the importance of the issues raised as a consequence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-We are discussing here, I suspect, the most famous refugee we have had in post-war Australia, Miss Liliana Gasinskaya. I suspect further that she is only famous because she is of Russian nationality. Following the statement of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) to the House today, I think that the young lady in question ought to realise that Australia has been exceedingly generous to her in the way in which she has been allowed to stay, for the status which has been granted to her and for the amount of attention and money that has been paid in all the inquiries that have taken place as a result of the matter being raised in this Parliament just a few weeks ago. There are many people in Australia, especially in the ethnic communities, who believe that perhaps she has received too favourable a treatment which is not available to people from other countries. They continually raise the question why this young lady, Miss Gasinskaya, should have treatment that is not available to other people. I have not checked today but certainly a few days ago there were people being held in the gaols of Australia awaiting deportation because they had virtually done exactly the same as Miss Gasinskaya; they had either jumped off their boat or come into Australia illegally and were awaiting deportation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that, at the time when Miss Gasinskaya claimed refugee status in Australia, a question was asked of the then Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the present Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar), as to how many people had been deported from the country during the period from January 1978 to March 1979. A total of 794 persons who had entered the country illegally had been deported and, in the same period, a total of 303 deportations were effected in respect of those persons who had entered Australia illegally. So we were really bending over backwards to allow this young Russian lady to stay. In addition, we had 151,000 people apply to migrate to Australia, and 80,000 of those, many of whom would have been families of people already living in Australia, had been refused entry. I think that it is much easier for the ethnic communities of Australia to try to rationalise these questions because they feel the unfairness perhaps more than the rest of the community. I am not suggesting for one moment that it is a responsibility that can be handed over to one section of the Australian community, but the ethnic community does feel the matter very deeply.

Whilst I have no quarrel with the way in which the Minister has acted in order that Miss Gasinskaya now has time to receive a reply from the Embassy of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, as she has now applied for the return of her Soviet citizenship with the intention of travelling back to the USSR, I suggest that she be given time to think about the matter. Obviously, from her actions since she came here and from the reports contained in the ministerial statement, sometimes she is not all that sure of what she has done and said. I think that she should dwell on the matter and be counselled very wisely about what the future may hold. She ought to realise now the sort of publicity that she attracts. When Peter Falconer raised the question of Miss Gasinskaya in the Parliament, the following news headlines appeared around Australia: 'The Red-Bikini Girl ''USSR holiday'' to be checked'; ' ''Red Bikini Girl'' denies Soviet visit'; 'TV man says ''bikini girl'' admitted trip'; 'Send Red Bikini Girl Back-MP'; ' ''Red bikini girl'' wants out'; and 'Red-Girl Lillian on Mat'. So, of the 14,500,000 people in this country she is one who attracts an undue amount of publicity. It would not be so bad if that publicity started and finished with the young lady in question, but it does not. We have some very, very important communities in this country. A lot of people from those communities come to the offices of members of Parliament repeatedly asking that representations be made to Ministers for other people to be allowed to stay here after they have entered the country illegally. As I said at the outset all of this has occurred primarily because the mentality in Australia is that anyone from the Soviet Union who applies to stay after coming here illegally must be allowed to stay as something dreadful will happen if he or she is sent back. That has always been the parameter within which a government has to operate.

I draw the attention of the House to one exception which, of course, was the case of the Russian violinist, Georgi Ermolenko who visited Australia some years ago during the period of the Whitlam Labor Administration. At one stage Mr Ermolenko said that he did not want to return to Russia with the musical group and then he changed his mind and said that he did want to go back. But there were people in Australia who said that he was not telling the truth and that he did not really want to go back and we should not let him go back. In fact unions in Western Australia took action. The Federated Clerks Union and the Transport Workers Union took industrial action to try to stop this young chap going back to Russia after he had told people he had conferred with the Government and private individuals in Western Australia, that he did want to return. It so happened that the government of the day had to use the Royal Australian Air Force to fly the musical group to Singapore to get them out of Australia. Subsequently the Ermolenko family applied for and were granted residence in Australia and they are still here today. I raise this matter because it seems extremely important to me that, if in the future someone wants to leave a Russian vessel to stay in Australia, the Australian public ought not to believe that the repercussions of a decision to allow that person to stay will cease with that decision. Tens of thousands of people who are affected by that decision will discuss it. A lot of people will disagree with it and a lot will believe that the person involved should be sent home to apply later to enter Australia, the same as everybody else.

As I said, I realise the political parameters within which we operate on such questions in Australia. I think it is totally unfair that it appears that Australia has one policy for people leaving the Soviet Union and another for people who come from the many countries of those communities which make up the Australian ethnic community. Of course great political play was made of the Ermolenko case in the parliaments. People tried to suggest that we were persecuting Ermolenko. The unions took action; and people were upset about the matter. The same thing has happened with the young lady in question, Liliana Gasinskaya. It appears that the tolerance of a lot of people in Australia is running out with this young lass. She ought to think very carefully about her future. She should keep out of the limelight of the media, as her actions are not helping in the decision-making processes concerning people who want to settle in this country. I think that we at least have to rationalise our thinking about people who want to stay in Australia after entering illegally. We took a very major step last year in altering the laws so that people were warned that there would be no future amnesties for those who had entered and were staying in this country illegally. I think that, as near as we can, we need one more law to apply to everybody.

I know that from time to time the Minister is going to have to use his discretion, but all the communities ought to understand and accept the decisions-I am sure they will-if one law applies to them all. If they believe that people are to be favoured because of their nationality, this will cause unrest in the ethnic communities among people who do come here legally, live here legally and try to bring their relations here. Perhaps, on the odd occasion, they are involved with someone who has come here illegally. In trying to keep such people here they are told that anybody who comes in illegally must be deported. It is a very sorry state that we have got into. I am sure that every member of this Parliament is familiar with the circumstances of making representations to the responsible Minister after the family of someone who has entered this country illegally comes into his or her office and asks for a case to be argued. I know from discussions I have had with the present Minister and with previous Ministers, both Liberal and Labor, that sometimes they can have up to 100 representations on the same case. People will go to different members of parliament and exercise every avenue available for a person to stay in Australia, but ultimately that person can still be refused permission to stay here. All of these things have to be taken into account when we are discussing the case of people such as Miss Liliana Gasinskaya. I hope that she will consider her case more seriously than she may have done in the past two years and that she will make up her mind quickly about what she wants to do. I hope that she will not attract further media sensationalism, which plays a very large part in upsetting the very important ethnic communities we have in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Customs Tariff Proposals No. 5 (1981).

The Customs Tariff Proposals I have just tabled relate to proposed alterations to the Customs Tariff Act 1966. Proposals No. 5, which operates from tomorrow, contains tariff changes resulting from the Government's decisions on recommendations by the Industries Assistance Commission in its reports on the iron and steel industry, and metal cans and canisters of iron or steel.

The Government has generally accepted the recommendations made by the Industries Assistance Commission in its report on the iron and steel industry. The effect of this decision is that certain basic products and hot-rolled and semi-finished materials will be dutiable at 5 per cent; that some coated flat products and cold finished materials, other than those of high alloy, will be dutiable at 10 per cent; that other coated and further worked products will phase from 25 per cent to 10 per cent over a five-year period; that high alloy steel products will be dutiable at 25 per cent for three years and will then phase by annual decreases of 2 percentage points to the long term rate of 15 per cent; that certain large bore steel pipe, and pipe and tube fittings, will phase from 25 per cent to 15 per cent over a five-year period; that other pipes and tubes will be dutiable at 15 per cent immediately; and that minimum rates will apply to a range of input materials and minor products.

In respect of the IAC's report on metal cans and canisters of iron or steel, the Government has accepted the recommendations. The effect of this decision is that imports of cans, canisters and similar containers, with the exception of certain jerricans, will be dutiable at 15 per cent. Jerricans having a capacity of between 15 and 25 litres will be dutiable at 30 per cent for 12 months and will then become dutiable at the long term rate of 25 per cent. A summary setting out the nature of the duty changes has been prepared and is being circulated to honourable members. I commend the Proposals to the House.

INTERJECT.PARA: The gross abuse of taxpayers' funds involved in the party political activities of the Government Information Unit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The stench of corruption today hangs over Canberra. This Government, which so earnestly preaches propriety, has been caught with its fist in the till. It has abused its authority in an utterly arrogant fashion and misused public funds in a totally inexcusable way. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has established a dirty tricks department on a scale not seen since the Nixon White House. It is a dirty tricks department that will do anything to anyone to ensure this man's survival. This Prime Minister, who demands loyalty and objectivity from the Public Service and who at the same time rejects the notion of public funding of political parties, has established a unit within the Public Service to work as an indispensable operational arm of the Liberal Party of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: In Australia, with our established system of party politics, there will always be close liaison between any government and the party organisation which supports it. Of fundamental importance, however, is the notion of separation of the political party on the one hand and the operations of the government on the other. The bureaucracy is accountable to Ministers and not to the political parties which they belong to and any fudging of this separation inevitably destroys democracy as the country falls into the hands of the non-elected faceless apparatchiks of the political parties who are answerable and accountable to no one except the big and anonymous backers of those parties.

In the last three years the Prime Minister has abandoned that important principle in an effort to tighten his grip on the control of this country. This is all part of the Prime Minister's total inability to cope with criticism and his total failure to account for his actions to anyone. He has avoided scrutiny more than any of his predecessors. He will not participate in debates in this Parliament. He will not debate with the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) in public. He will not subject himself to the scrutiny of the media, except in a most perfunctory way and even then only to a selected portion of the Press gallery. He is a Prime Minister who is running scared; he is driven by the fear that someone will one day pin him down and find him out. He has cocooned himself behind the protection of his handlers in his Press office, who in turn behave as if he is some sort of punch drunk zombie not to be let out of their sight or control. It is therefore a simple and predictable extension to establish the mechanism for controlling the news in the hope that the Government and the Prime Minister will always be portrayed in the best possible light.

The Prime Minister has instituted a series of regular dinners with newspaper editors-browbeating sessions to ensure that the metropolitan dailies mirror the world according to the Prime Minister. Apparently that exercise has been less than totally successful. Some newspapers have deviated and have dared to contest the views of this man. His response, therefore, has been to establish the Government Information Unit. The Government Information Unit and its State appendages, the State Co-ordination Officers, was established in 1979 with a staff of eight people. It has grown so much in the last month that it now has a staff of 18. All these 18 members of the Government Information Unit are members of the Public Service. I invite honourable members to turn to page 38 of the Commonwealth Government Directory, where a special page is set aside for this peculiar organisation.

It is indisputably a part of the Public Service. As Senator Carrick said in the Senate a few days ago, these people work for the government of the day. That is, if there were a change of government, we, God bless us, would be left with Messrs Matthews and Hall. The cost of this Unit is now running at a level of half a million dollars a year.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—The Minister said that this is not true. He will have an opportunity to explain exactly how much it does cost. He might also explain who paid Mr Matthews's $4,000 bill when he was put up at the Windsor Hotel during the last Federal election campaign. The functions of the Unit are described quaintly in the Commonwealth Government Directory as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: To assist Ministers in communication matters and in the projection of Government policies.
The State co-ordination officers' functions are described as follows:
To assist Ministers in their dealings with matters affecting the States concerned and to keep the Government in touch with public reaction to Government policies and programs.

That all seems innocuous enough until we realise the true purpose of this totally sinister organisation. In fact, the Unit exists for two main reasons. Firstly, it exists to manage the news and to ensure that only the government line is reported. This is achieved by ensuring that Ministers are inaccessible to the Press and also by ensuring that all Government statements are released through the Unit, as far as possible, in such a way as to circumvent the Press Gallery. The Unit is about to embark on a program of distributing carefully prepared tapes for use by the electronic media. There will be no chance to question. One will have the opportunity simply to play these carefully sanitised Government opinions. This is only the beginning. Unless someone takes a stand-it is a stand which will have to be taken by the Press-the freedom of the Press is at risk from these news managers as they attempt to eliminate altogether the need for journalists and reporters.

The second main function of the unit is to service the Liberal Party. Indeed, the Liberal Party secretariat clearly considers that the Unit is its own. During the last Federal election campaign the Unit played an indispensible role in the running of the Liberal Party campaign. The involvement of the Unit was carefully planned from the earliest stage of the Liberal Party's campaign. I refer honourable members to a document entitled: 'Campaign HQ: Agenda' which states:
Herewith the agenda for the meeting on Thursday morning to discuss the structure and operations of the campaign headquarters.
It is signed:
Jackie (for TE)

There are no prizes for guessing who T.E. might be. From this agenda paper it is perfectly clear that the Government Information Unit and its operations were discussed at the campaign meeting. In item 5 of the agenda for this meeting under the heading 'Operations', amongst a whole list of other organisations with whom the Party has dealings-quite properly, in most instances-we find the words: 'Liaison with Government Information Unit'. Further, the Federal secretariat is given the task of liaising with the Government Information Unit. So from the very outset this Unit was expected to be involved in an intricate way with the campaign.
On 26 and 27 June the Federal Liberal Party conducted a campaign seminar. When discussing the question of the co-ordination of ministerial visits the following paragraph appears:
On arrival in the State, their first port of call-
That is the Ministers-
should be the office of the Minister to whom the State Co-ordinator Officer is attached, for a briefing on the local campaign climate.

Further, we have an indication of a discussion which took place concerning what should happen in relation to the itinerary of the Prime Minister. Consult with State director--
That is the State director of the Liberal Party-
and State co-ordination officer to obtain input for initial 'political climate' report for the PM and the Federal campaign director.

That is the State Director of the Liberal Party-
should liaise with the State co-ordination officer--
That is of the Government Information Unit-
about the filing of a 'political' climate update. (This should reach the Prime Minister and the Federal Director no later than 24 hours prior to the start of the visit.)

Clearly, what we see here is that the Unit is to provide a briefing or report on the local political climate as it exists in each State. Obviously this is a highly political task, so political in fact that the local director of the Liberal Party has to be involved in its compilation. When that report is prepared it is sent not simply to the Prime Minister but to the Federal Director of the Liberal Party. This is a scandalous abuse of the Public Service. This sort of task is a task for the political parties to carry out. It is not a task for public servants to carry out. But I think what has happened is that the Government Information Unit has recognised that its true master is, in fact, Mr Eggleton.

On 25 August a monitoring meeting was held. Eddie--

to ask SCOs--

to report daily on placement of press ads.

SPEECH.PARA: This debate reflects a great deal of what has been happening in recent weeks. It all boils down to simple whinging by the Australian Labor Party. The Labor Party was thrashed in the last Federal election. It tried to dispute the verdict of the people by taking a spurious case to the High Court of Australia. The High Court, quite rightly, threw out the matter. There is a close link between the whinging in relation to the case which the Labor Party took to the courts and the protests we have heard today and over recent weeks about the establishment of the Government Information Unit. The Opposition is hell-bent on grossly misrepresenting the Government's intentions and motives and is definitely exaggerating and deliberately misrepresenting how the Government Information Unit works. What the Opposition is really about is attempting to destroy the Government Information Unit. That is the case for one reason and one reason only. It is desperately afraid that the Australian people will be kept informed on what this Government is doing and why it is doing it. The Government Information Unit has been eminently successful in fulfilling that function. The Labor Party has set out to destroy it because it is frightened of it. It is frightened that the Unit will continue successfully.

The Labor Party is afraid that the steady flow of factual information about policies and decisions of this Government will make it all the more difficult for the ALP to mislead and misrepresent. Let me repeat to all members of the House: We make no apology for providing an information and Press service for the Government and the Ministers who require it. The Information Unit will continue to assist and advise Ministers. It will not simply put out Press statements and leave it at that, but will assist and advise Ministers on the basis of how best to communicate with the Australian people, make Ministers more accessible to the media by planning and arranging media coverage, assist journalists in their task of reporting the affairs of the Government, and make the Government more aware of issues in the States which are relevant to the Commonwealth. We all accept that in a Federal system it is essential that Government Ministers, who spend so much of their time in Canberra, should be kept fully informed of what is said and reported in the States.

I said a moment ago that the Labor Party had deliberately set out to mislead and misrepresent the Government to the people. To illustrate this point, there is no better example than that of the honourable member for Fremantle who, in the discussion today and on the radio broadcast this morning, sought to give the impression that members of the Government Information Unit were permanent public servants. That is a falsehood. They are not permanent public servants. They are employed on the same basis as the staff of Ministers and office holders. They are directly under the control of Ministers. Furthermore, they can be dismissed on a fortnight's notice. They are of the same political nature as Press officers, speech writers or ministerial officers employed by Government Ministers or Opposition members. They differ from other ministerial officers in one respect only. They have a responsibility to make their services available to all Ministers as they are required rather than being on the staff of one single Minister. As would be expected, they have a responsibility to maintain relations on a day to day basis with Ministers and with the States as appropriate. Naturally, during election campaigns they continue to service the Government as do speech writers and Press secretaries of the Opposition.

I have set out the position in respect of the Government Information Unit, its functions, and the composition of its staff. It is a modest, and therefore economical, approach to providing Press support for the Ministers of the Government. Its cost is not $500,000 plus, as the honourable member for Fremantle so glibly tried to tell us. This year the Unit's appropriation is about $388,000. Let us compare this staff with that of the Whitlam Government and that of other State Labor governments at the moment. In the last Federal Labor Government there was provision for 27 Press secretaries to the Prime Minister and Ministers. That is bad enough, compared with the modest arrangements that we have made but, in addition to that, the Labor Government established the Australian Government Liaison Service. The Service consisted of 13 journalists, two clerks, five clerical assistants, one assistant printer and two typists. To top all that, it also established the Department of the Media to which it appointed one of its socialist cronies, Mr Spigelman. The Labor Government appointed him as the permanent head of a department of state. Mr Spigelman presided over a massive propaganda organisation within the Department of the Media. That Department had a budget of $17m. My colleague, the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Donald Cameron), will probably describe that in a little more detail. What the situation added up to was a permanent head appointed to preside over a department of state, a major function of which was to provide a vast propaganda machine which had a capacity to employ over 40 Press secretaries.

1. During the campaign proper Ministers will be asked by the Prime Minister to undertake one of the following roles-

(c) State Specialists: Ministers who will undertake general campaign activities within their States.
Travelling Ministers
2. The aim with each Travelling Minister is to design an itinerary which maximises publicity for the Government both nationally and in each State he visits.

(a) the need to use Ministers to the best possible advantage during the campaign;
(b) the wishes of both the Ministers themselves and the State Divisions;

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Thomson, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is concerned with one of the ways in which the registered proprietor of a trade mark can protect his rights. In particular, it relates to section 103 of the Trade Marks Act 1955 which, in some circumstances, prohibits the import into Australia of goods bearing a registered trade mark. The Government, through the operation of the Trade Marks Office, is committed to the promotion of orderly development of trade, industry and commerce by the protection of trade marks, whether they be for goods or services. This Bill seeks to give effect to that commitment in the area of importing of goods bearing a registered trade mark.

A trade mark indicates that goods or services bearing the mark come from a particular trade source. It is a kind of property, able to be bought and sold. It is part of the family of intellectual property which also includes patents, industrial designs and copyright. Since a trade mark is a kind of property, it carries a principal feature of property, the right to exclude others from using it.

This right to exclude others may be enforced in different ways. First, there is the common law remedy known as 'passing-off'. In appropriate circumstances the courts will protect a trader who has built up a reputation in a trade mark, usually by long, extensive, continuous and exclusive use. The basic idea behind this is to protect the public against deception. However, the 'passing-off' remedy is cumbersome and expensive, since the trader has to prove his reputation by calling witnesses into court.

TALK.START.PARA: —You mean a remedy against 'passing-off'.

—Yes, a remedy against 'passing-off'. Therefore provisions were included in the trade mark legislation to solve this problem. The Trade Marks Act provides quick proof and quick machinery for enforcing trade mark rights through a system of trade mark registration. A trader may apply to the Registrar of Trade Marks for registration. If the Registrar considers the trade mark is one which the Act says he can or must register he will accept the mark. The trade mark will be placed on the register after the public has been given the opportunity to object. The registered trade mark can then be protected by an infringement action for which production of the registration certificate is sufficient proof of ownership of the trade mark. The remedy of infringement proceedings under the Trade Marks Act is the second way a trade mark owner can protect his rights.

SPEECH.PARA: A third protective remedy is section 103 of the Act. This allows for the prohibition, under some circumstances, of imported goods manufactured outside Australia which bear a trade mark registered in Australia. The registered proprietor or registered user of the trade mark can notify Customs that he objects to goods bearing the mark being imported. This objection enables Customs to seize such goods. It is not hard, for example, to see the value of this remedy where pirate goods bear forged or falsely applied trade marks. Section 103 effectively protects the proprietor or registered user against encroachment on his rights by unscrupulous overseas manufacturers. However, the use of section 103 to prevent the import of genuinely marked goods has caused concern. This includes cases where the trade mark was applied overseas by the same company which is the registered proprietor in Australia.

Many object to this use of the section, saying it goes too far beyond the ideas behind protecting trade marks and abuses the purpose behind protecting trade marks by registration. The use of section 103 in relation to the importation of goods was therefore referred to the Industrial Property Advisory Committee for review. That Committee's recommendations have generally been accepted by the Government. This Bill is designed to amend section 103 to implement the report. The Committee's key recommendation is that the provisions for seizure and forfeiture of goods under section 103 should be confined to those cases where importation infringes a registered trade mark.

Section 103 will no longer be available to prevent the import of goods bearing a genuine trade mark applied overseas by the Australian registered proprietor. It would still protect against pirate goods, provided that the import of those goods constituted an infringement of the registered trade mark. This brings section 103 into line with the philosophy of the rest of the Trade Marks Act, providing a convenient and effective means of enforcing the same civil rights protectable under infringement proceedings. Section103 will therefore apply only in situations where the trader's reputation might suffer and where the public might be deceived.

The Bill gives effect to the Committee's recommendation that the mechanism of notifying Customs be retained. Section 103 is available to any registered proprietor of a trade mark registered in Australia, and also to registered users. Procedures laid down are consistent with tying section 103 to the test of infringement. This Bill ensures the rights of the registered proprietor and the consuming public are adequately protected against the import of goods infringing trade marks. At the same time the Bill eliminates undesirable practices which have grown up under the current provisions. I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT INCENTIVES AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Thomson, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Bill is to enable the Government to implement important elements of a new policy for industrial research and development grants. It will also allow another five-year program for industrial research and development incentives. The Bill is part of the Government's response to the report of the Committee of Inquiry into Technological Change in Australia which was announced in the House on 18 September 1980. Our general objective is to make the Australian manufacturing sector more export oriented and more competitive against imports. A major factor in achieving this objective will be the success of the Government's general economic policy. As well, the Government's general industry policy approach has two broad strands: Firstly, to give encouragement to activities which are efficient, internationally competitive and export oriented by such measures as export, innovation and investment incentives; and secondly, to achieve, in the long term, an industry structure requiring minimum levels of government support.

The existing Act, which expires on 30 June this year, was introduced in 1976 and provides for funding commencement and project grants as well as projects of industrial research considered to be in the public interest. This Government believes it is vital to encourage industrial research and development. Funding has risen from $14 in 1977-78 to $54m in 1980-81-nearly a four-fold rise within three years-despite the need for continuing expenditure restraints. Under the new program, commencement and project grants and public interest projects are to continue for a further five years. However they are to be brought more into line with the other aims of the Government industrial development policy. Project grants will remain the main focus of the new program.

Recently the Government has been urged to stimulate industrial research and development by a number of expert committees including the Committee of Inquiry into Technological Change in Australia, and the Australian Science and Technology Council. Their advice was taken into consideration in developing the program which I am about to announce. Basically the Government has decided to become more selective in providing assistance. The rationale for government assistance rests on the proposition that there are disparities between the private and national returns from research and development expenditure. The market does not provide enough incentives for firms to undertake research and development. The result is a national under-investment in industrial research and development and a tendency for firms to concentrate on relatively short-term industrial research and development.

TALK.START.PARA: —And inadequate, too

—I am glad that the honourable member for Lalor agrees. The fundamental purpose of the program is to correct this market failure. Against this background, the Government has decided that, in future, an industrial research and development project will be supported only where it involves a substantial degree of risk or where a firm is unable to gain enough of the profits generated from the industrial research and development to justify the project. The Government has also decided that policy measures should be cost effective, be designed to improve rather than impede the operations of the market and that objectives should be spelled out clearly.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill proposes that regulations be promulgated to ensure that project grant applications are ranked according to their potential contribution to industry policy objectives. However, for practical timing and flexibility reasons, I propose that initially these guidelines be issued to the Board as directions under section 19 of the principal Act. Firms will be required to maintain a sizable financial stake in subsidised industrial research and development to ensure their motivation for success is not diminished. To compensate for inflation as well as to strengthen the incentive to firms to undertake the industrial research and development, the Government proposes to increase ceilings from $500,000 to $750,000 per year for project grants and from $25,000 to $40,000 per year for commencement grants. The grants will remain taxable. For ongoing commencement grants the rate for the following year will be announced on 31 March and will not exceed 50 per cent. The project grant rate shall not exceed 50 per cent without ministerial approval.

The Bill makes provision for the inclusion of industrial research and development related to and carried out at the site of a building and is retrospective to 1 July 1980. I am sure the building industry will be very pleased with this announcement. Eligibility does not extend to more general operations in the industry such as works. The Bill also allows computer software research and development to be eligible for project grant assistance under the Act, but only when it is relevant to the objectives of the Act. It must relate directly to new products of, and new or improved processes employed in manufacturing, mining or eligible on-site building or construction activities.

The Government's intention is to encourage the application of new or innovative software techniques to the development of such products or processes. However, where computer software research and development has been eligible under the commencement grant scheme, this eligibility will be retained after 1 July 1981. In accordance with CITCA recommendations and with Government decisions on that report, the Bill includes a section on the Board's powers and functions. In broad terms, these are: To authorise the payment of industrial research and development commencement grants to eligible companies; to enter into agreements for projects of industrial research and development carried out or proposed to be carried out by eligible companies; and to enter into contracts for projects of industrial research in a field of science and technology where, as Minister, I consider this to be in the public interest. The Board will be restructured and chaired by someone outside the Public Service.

The Bill contains provisions to enable the Board to obtain specialised advice in technical and commercial areas. As Minister, I shall obtain advice on the selection of public interest projects by a re-constituted IR & D Incentives Advisory Committee. The Advisory Committee shall take into account certain guidelines. The project must, firstly, be of high priority in terms of Government policy objectives; secondly, have substantial social and economic benefit for the community; thirdly, normally involve the commercial development of public sector or non-profit research institutions; and, fourthly, be of major importance and likely to command widespread public support. As well, the guidelines will specify that funding should be for industrial research and development and not be in the place of other funding sources.

Ownership of the results of public interest projects will be vested in the Commonwealth Government, with commercially viable prospects being exploited on normal business terms. In future the Board's annual report will include statements giving the names of companies with which the Board has made arrangements, the progress of their projects, and payments made to them. Directions from the Minister to the Board will also be included.

The Bill repeals the Industrial Research and Development Grants Act 1967. The Government will be monitoring the operation of the new scheme, to evaluate its effectiveness against the principles which I have just outlined, prior to the Act's expiry in 1986. I commend the Bill to the House.
