PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 April, on motion by Mr Hunt:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of this Bill is to authorise the Treasurer (Mr Howard) to provide Commonwealth loan guarantees to Ansett Transport Industries Ltd and an unnamed subsidiary up to a limit of $US490m. The guarantees will enable Ansett to conclude purchase arrangements for 21 new Boeing aircraft, which will be programmed for delivery between June 1981 and late 1985. The 12 Boeing 737 series aircraft to be purchased are old technology, noisy aircraft which will exacerbate noise pollution problems at Mascot airport. The Government's approval of the import of these aircraft strikes out the major recommendation of the Government's Major Airport Needs of Sydney Committee-that new technology, quiet, wide-bodied aircraft should be introduced during the 1980s to replace smaller and noisier aircraft currently in use. The provision of Australian Government guarantees to Ansett and Trans-Australia Airlines in respect of loans raised abroad to purchase new passenger aircraft is a basic feature of the two-airline policy. Similar guarantees have been provided to Ansett Transport Industries Ltd on 21 previous occasions since 1966-67, and on one occasion to Trans-Australia Airlines, last year.

SPEECH.PARA: As at 31 December 1980, the Commonwealth's contingent liability in respect of overseas Ansett loans stood at $US57.2m and in respect of TAA at $US34m. Traditionally, Airlines Equipment (Loan Guarantee) Bills have not been objected to by the Opposition. However, in view of the grave and exceptional circumstances that are associated with this Bill, at a later stage I will move that consideration of it be postponed.

Before dealing with the Bill I propose to comment on some of the statements that have been made by the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) in his second reading speech. The Minister re- affirmed that the Government had decided to transform Trans-Australia Airlines into a public company. There is no doubt that the Government intends to sell all or part of TAA to its wealthy friends and stock exchange speculators. TAA has been an innovative and successful public enterprise. Its sale would rob the 90 per cent of Australians who do not hold shares in public companies of their ownership of this famous airline, of this valuable national asset which is a symbol of national public enterprise achievement and of national spirit. Its sale to private enterprise would constitute misappropriation of public property and would be resisted at every opportunity by the Australian Labor Party. My Leader and my colleagues will respond later in the debate in more detail to this aspect of the Minister's comments.

The Minister also referred to the Government's decision to establish an independent fare tribunal. The use of a tribunal to process publicly applications for air fare increases has been Australian Labor Party policy at the last two elections, and we welcome this step in the direction of our policy. If the tribunal is to be truly independent and not just an acquiescent appendage of the Department of Transport, as is the so-called independent Office of Road Safety, and if the tribunal conducts public hearings on fare increase applications, it will receive the full backing of the Opposition.

The Minister used his second reading speech as a subterfuge to announce that an inquiry was to be conducted, at some time between now and 1986, into the desirability of the deregulation of the airline industry in the long term. By making the announcement late in the evening he hoped to prevent parliamentary response on a matter which ought properly to have been the subject of a separate statement to the Parliament. It is now evident, that, following a threatened rebellion in the Government caucus against this Bill last Thursday, a deal was concluded to establish an inquiry into airline deregulation if the rebels would support this measure. The hapless, embattled Minister for Transport told the Government caucus that the Bill concerned the purchase of one aircraft only. Subsequently he had to be advised that the purchase of 21 aircraft was involved. The rebels were jubilant when the inquiry was announced. However, the indications are that their victory was a hollow one; that they have been fooled again by the Government. The inquiry, in the form outlined, was a sop to those gullible back bench rebels. The Minister, in announcing it last Thursday evening, could not tell the House who would conduct it, where it would be held, when it would be held, what its terms of reference might be or even when it might be commenced. But he seemed fairly confident that it would report by 1986-if by some mischance this incompetent Government were returned at the next elections.

The servile attitude of the Government to the proprietors of Ansett was again shown by the Minister for Transport in announcing the inquiry. He told the House that he was confident that TAA and Ansett would co-operate, despite the almost unlimited legislative powers that he has to require both airlines to supply all relevant financial and operational information. It will be recalled that he made a similar statement when the Holcroft inquiry was announced. The record shows that his confidence on that occasion was misplaced. Ansett did not co-operate or make a substantive submission to that inquiry.

Let me make clear the position of the Opposition on the deregulation inquiry. If it is to be a public inquiry, if it is to receive the full support of, and access to, the resources of the Department of Transport, if its task is to be completed within a reasonable period, say one year, and if it is to be given the power to compel the airlines to present all relevant information, it will have the full support of the Australian Labor Party. However, in the form announced, the inquiry amounts to no more than a sop to the deregulations rebels in the Government caucus. It is an impromptu, token inquiry offered to appease the opponents in the Government's ranks of the Government's policy, and the proposed massive public guarantee of almost $US500m sought under the Bill. The five-year reporting period for the inquiry means that the Government does not intend to take any firm action on airline regulation or deregulation before the 1983 elections.

I turn now to the Bill before us. The manner in which this legislation has been approved by Government caucus and presented to the Parliament for urgent passage is a matter for grave public concern. The Bill has resulted from brawling amongst Government members following the collapse of the Government's aviation policy. We have now a situation in which the Government's aviation policy is being determined on the hour, by the hour, and this Bill is being handled by a Minister who did not know how many aircraft were involved and who, I am satisfied, does not appreciate fully the implications of the legislation, which was introduced late last Thursday evening and is to be rammed through the Parliament this week at the behest of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). The proposed guarantee of the $US490m borrowing for Ansett involves the largest amount sought by any airline in this country's history. In the circumstances, Parliament should have been given full information on the loans to be guaranteed and the purposes to which they were to be applied.

The Minister's second reading speech was scandalous for its sparsity and its exclusions. In a departure from standard practice, the Bill does not stipulate the percentage of the aircraft purchase price that can be the subject of Commonwealth guarantee. Despite repeated requests from the Opposition in earlier identical debates, the Minister for Transport has again failed to advance any evidence for the justification of a financial need by Ansett of $US490m. Unlike previous loan guarantee Bills, the Ansett subsidiary concerned with these guarantees is not named. It ought to have been specified in the provisions of the Bill. Clause 4 of the Bill stipulates that the proceeds of the loans raised by Ansett are to be used for the purchase of the 21 aircraft itemised and related spare parts and equipment. However, most interestingly in the publicity associated with the provision of the Eximbank loans to Ansett, there is reference to the provision of an amount of money, in total $US34.2m, for purposes related to publicity and other matters. I will come back to that subject a little later. Clause 5 sets out the conditions of the guarantees to be provided. It gives the Minister extensive powers, which the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares highlighted that the Minister had failed to exercise in the past. He had failed to exercise those extensive powers of access to the financial accounts of Ansett and its subsidiaries.

The Ansett loans affair has become a matter of much notoriety in the United States of America. It is regrettable that an Australian company should be the subject of such notoriety in the United States Press and the attention of so much concern and activity by the United States Government agencies, especially when it is a company that is so dependent on legislative protection for its financial success. There are in- volved here a series of loans from the United States Export-Import Bank-Eximbank-to Ansett Transport Industries associated with this legislation. Yet the Minister, in his second reading speech, most of which he devoted to matters not relevant to the Bill, made no mention of the individual loans involved or the series of loans in- volved, nor did he provide any advice to Parliament on the public concern and the investigations in the United States at the manner in which the Eximbank loans were arranged and the purposes to which the proceeds of those loans may be put. In what was a patently false statement the Prime Minister claimed last Friday that this legislation had to be passed before Easter. Let me quote from a transcript of his Press conference. It does not read correctly; it is as the Prime Minister said it. The transcript reads:

We have to get this legislation through before Easter, because the guarantees are needed. The Ansett group, in fulfilling that loan with the Exim Bank and we are not prepared to run the risk of going over the time scales in relation to that because that would probably force Ansett into a renogotiation with Exim and that would have all sorts of complications and difficulties which nobody would want.

Let me say to honourable members that the people of Australia are likely to be locked into a guarantee for almost $US500m and they very much want to know what are the complications and the difficulties associated with the Eximbank loans being made to Ansett Transport Industries. In those few words the Prime Minister took the course of concealing what is a very serious issue in the United States, an issue to which this Government does not want to address itself. I ask the Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport to elaborate to this Parliament and to the people of Australia what the complications and difficulties are which the Prime Minister is so concerned about in respect of Ansett Transport Industries and Eximbank, that he does not want to risk a renegotiation of those loans. Let me remind him and those honourable members who sit opposite that they are sent here by the people of Australia to protect their interests, not to protect the interests of the Government's wealthy backers in private commerce. The Minister for Transport carefuly refrained from mentioning the Eximbank loans in his speech. He made no mention of any urgency or deadline for the provision of the guarantees. No evidence has been provided to the Parliament that there is a deadline to meet; nor has there been any mention of anything to support what the Prime Minister said last Friday at his Press conference.

The evidence that is publicly available indicates the opposite of what the Prime Minister said. In fact, the Prime Minister, by rushing this Bill through, is seeking to protect Ansett in its difficulties in the United States. Obviously he wants to give the Ansett Transport Industries loan applications added status by providing the company with Australian Government guarantees before the current United States investigations into the circumstances of the Eximbank loans are completed. Obviously he wants Ansett to be able to say: 'Look, what are you arguing about and questioning? These loans have already received legislative guarantee from the Australian Government. There could not possibly be anything wrong with the manner in which these loans were obtained.' That is not good enough. The responsibility of the Prime Minister should be to see that the public interest is protected and that there is propriety in all dealings of Australian companies abroad, particularly when they have the very strong legislative backing of this Parliament. I mentioned earlier that the Ansett loans affair has attracted much notoriety in the United States partly because of the manner in which the loans were arranged and partly because there is a large public subsidy, from the United States taxpayers, involved in the low interest rates available to Ansett through Eximbank.

There is around this issue a stench arising from the manner in which this Bill has been presented to the Parliament and is being rushed through; a stench arising from the failure of the Minister for Transport to inform the Parliament of the questionable circumstances associated with the Eximbank loans to Ansett Transport Industries; a stench arising from the persistent preferential treatment accorded Ansett Airlines by this Government, this Minister for Transport and this Prime Minister; and a stench arising from the relationship between this Government and the proprietors of Ansett Airlines and the Ansett Press. There is a smell of corruption hanging over the Ansett loans affair. The course that this Government is proposing to follow may even be illegal. It is certainly immoral. The Australian Treasury has very strict regulations with respect to loans and Commonwealth guarantees for loans. Can the Minister for Transport really tell this Parliament that the procedure he is proposing to adopt to guarantee loans by the people of Australia of almost $US500m-loans which are presently under active federal investigation in the country where they are being made-without even waiting for preliminary reports on those investigations is legal and is a responsible course?

On 26 March, almost two weeks ago, I asked the Minister for Transport-it is recorded on page 951 of Hansard of that date-several specific questions related to contingent liabilities associated with the Eximbank loans to Ansett. It was clear to the House from the answer of the Minister for Transport that he did not understand or appreciate the seriousness or the thrust of the questions. He said that he had no doubt that the Treasury had been examining all of the details associated with the loans. Let me remind him again; he is the Minister presenting this legislation to the Parliament. He and his Department have a responsibility to see that all of the Treasury regulations and directions are being complied with in respect of the provision of Commonwealth guarantees for loans being raised by this company. It is not good enough and it is not acceptable for the Minister for Transport to brush aside a serious issue like this and say that it is the responsibility of the Treasurer. Public servants do not stand for election and they are not accountable. It is the Minister at the table and the members of the Government who stand for election and who are accountable to this Parliament and to the people of Australia. In the two weeks since I asked the question not a word has come from the Treasurer or from the Minister for Transport on any contingent liabilities existing, the possibility of added contingent liabilities that may arise following the United States investigations of the loans or the nature and the course of investigations. It is traditional practice in this House-it would have been common courtesy-that when a question of that nature is asked and the Minister concerned is not able to provide information or when he says that the matter falls within the responsibility of another Minister, that information is provided in written form or by a statement to the House at a later stage. Neither of those courses has been adopted in respect of that question or in respect of this very serious matter.

On 25 March this year Senator Proxmire of the United States Senate Banking Committee asked Eximbank to suspend the Ansett loans until the high-powered United States General Accounting Office had completed its investigation into the terms of the Boeing sale to Ansett. Senator Proxmire had this to say:
I believe the public interest required that upon completion of the General Accounting Office report, Ex-Im--
That is the Bank-
re-examine the loans to determine whether approval or denial is the appropriate course of action.

Senator John Heinz-this is most significant because he is now in the majority party in the Senate-the chairman of the Sub-Comittee on International Finance, joined Senator Proxmire in calling for a review of the loan. Senator Heinz said that the Eximbank board would be well advised to honour Senator Proxmire's request. Senator Heinz added:
I think it would be a good idea for the new chairman to look at the whole Ansett financing arrangement.

That is the kind of discussion that has been taking place in the United States where these loans are being raised and provided at a major cost to United States taxpayers. But in this Parliament, under this Government and its Minister, there has not been one word, whisper or even suggestion; there has been only an assertion from the Prime Minister that some sort of phantom deadline had to be met. The Prime Minister was really saying: 'Let us get this legislation through quickly; let us make Ansett look better in the light of those investigations; and let us not talk about any of the problems or difficulties associated with those loans'.

On 31 March the Eximbank deferred to a future date approval of the $US289m loan to Ansett. The public record shows that the Ansett-Eximbank loans are currently under investigation by the following bodies: the United States Senate Banking Committee; the powerful General Accounting Office to which I have already referred-the organisation is much more powerful than the Auditor-General or the Public Accounts Committee of this Parliament and is reportable to the United States legislature-the administrative officers of the Eximbank itself; and the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The Australian Broadcasting Commission A.M. program reported on 26 March this year:

The American Justice Department has announced that the FBI is to begin investigating the circumstances surrounding the $200m loan to Ansett from America's Export Import Bank. The new complaint comes from the Public Integrity Section within the Justice Department and a spokesman, Mr John Russell, said that the FBI agents in particular would be probing whether politics had played a part in the granting of the Ansett loan.
The report concluded:
Never before--
I stress this statement-
has the American Congress approved legislation or a joint resolution to try to deny one of the American bank's foreign loans.
Again, nothing happened here. There was paralysis because this Government and this Prime Minister know who their political masters are; they are captives of the proprietors of Ansett Airlines.

It is significant, as I mentioned earlier, that Senator Heinz joined Senator Proxmire in expressing concern at the Ansett loan. A bipartisan decision was reached by two senators from both sides of the committee which examined this matter. The integrity of these men is very high in the United States Senate; their credentials are very highly regarded by the United States people. Here, in contrast, the Australian Prime Minister sought to gloss over the grave questions raised in the United States on the Ansett loan. The hapless Minister for Transport does not want to know about it. He cannot even get the number of aircraft right. Both of them have embarked on a process of guaranteeing loans, the very probity and legality of which have been called into most serious question by senior legislators in the United States Senate. That legislature at least has the public integrity to demand answers to the same questions I am now asking and to defer approval of the loan until satisfactory answers are forthcoming.

A little later in this debate I will move an amendment. I ask those honourable members opposite who have integrity and probity to join the Opposition and support this very responsible and proper amendment which states that consideration of this legislation be deferred until the outcome of the United States investigations is known. If they do not it will mean one thing-that those honourable members opposite disregard the decisions of the United States senators, the Senate committees concerned, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the other agencies I have mentioned. It will mean that honourable members opposite, the Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport are prepared to risk the liability that would be incurred by the Australian people in entering into an agreement and a guarantee that afterwards may be found to be legally faulty. Where are the men opposite with integrity and the stature of Senator Proxmire who are prepared to elevate public accountability over cronyism and favouritism to the wealthy friends and political masters of this Government? If there are any I invite them as men of integrity to join the Opposition in supporting my amendment when a division is called.

The Government is aware of all the aspects of the Ansett loans affair to which I have referred. It would have senior Treasury officials following the United States inquiries and events, and no doubt those officials have been reporting on the progress. It would be aware of the United States allegations of political favours and kickbacks associated with the Ansett loans. It would be aware that the Eximbank was not informed of the funds being provided through the loans to Ansett and of matters that were not associated directly with the purchase of the aircraft and related spares and equipment. The charges involved in these United States inquiries are serious and need to be cleared up before the people of this country are locked into a liability of almost $US500m.

There is no certainty as to the outcome of the United States investigations. The loans could be cancelled, they could be reduced or they could be endorsed. But we have a responsibility to protect the Australian public interest by ensuring that we do not enter into a liability that is found subsequently to be faulty and illegal. It would be utterly irresponsible to pass the Bill before us into law without the benefit of the result of those inquiries and the decisions of the United States legislature. I have shown that there is no deadline for the legislation. I have shown that serious matters are being questioned in the United States. I have shown that there are serious allegations as to the propriety of the loans and the manner in which they were negotiated. I have pointed out that since the United States elections of late last year the incoming majority party in the Senate has also taken up the question of the propriety of those loans. In all these circumstances I move:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'Consideration of the Bill be postponed pending the outcome of inquiries being conducted in the United States of America by the Senate Banking Committee, the General Accounting Office and the Federal Bureau of Investigation into the circumstances of the United States Export-Import Bank loans to Ansett Transport Industries Limited and its subsidiary'.

In the few minutes remaining to me I want briefly to comment on the aircraft that are being purchased as a result of the loans that may be raised and which are associated with the legislation before us. I want to refer to the decision of the airlines, particularly Ansett, to choose differing aircraft. That decision has been trumpeted by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport as being one that will increase competition and reduce the cost of air travel in this country.

I do not want to make any assertions. I will simply quote someone who has much greater experience and much higher qualifications than I in the air transport industry. I refer to a statement by Mr Lyn McKenzie, the former general manager of TAA, a man with impeccable credentials and a man highly respected in the airline industry. Mr Deputy Speaker, I do not like the Minister's advisers laughing at my comments. If they do not like them, will they leave the chamber or conduct themselves with propriety? On 10 September last Mr McKenzie told the New South Wales Chartered Institute of Transport of Ansett's decision to buy differing aircraft. He is reported in a newspaper article as saying that this would force up fares and would not end parallel scheduling. He also criticised Ansett Airlines for buying differing wide-bodied aircraft. He is reported as saying:
The two different major aircraft types provide the consumer with a choice, but the consumer will have to pay for the privilege.
He went on to say:

But it is a big price to pay, particularly as the current attitude of the airlines seems to be towards seeking strong Government support for reducing competition to improve yield by enforcing the elimination of all marketing initiatives so much in evidence only a short time ago.
He also said:
The extra costs will have to be passed on in fares.
The current trend with passenger traffic seems to be towards a severe tightening of controls and the complete elimination of the greater flexibility seen in more recent times.
No doubt this is designed to improve yields to meet higher costs incurred in part by service innovations recently introduced for competitive reasons.

I wish to refer now to another man of equally impeccable credentials, who is also very highly respected in the airline industry. I speak of the Director of Engineering in Ansett Airlines, Mr John Warner. In a paper he delivered last year dealing with the introduction of new aircraft by Ansett, he had this to say:
There is an element of risk with the purchase of the Boeing 767s wide-bodied jets as yet untested and commercially untried.
He stated:
. . . a cardinal rule has not been followed in the case of the purchase of new 767s in that an airline needs 2 years input to evaluate a new jet aircraft.

I offer those comments to honourable members opposite and to my colleagues as comments along similar lines made by two men of very high standing with a lifetime of experience in the airline industry, one from Ansett and one from the public airline, Trans-Australia Airlines. Those comments throw considerable doubt upon the claims of the Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport that the choice of differing aircraft is a step forward. I commend the amendment to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take pleasure in seconding the amendment and reserve my right to speak at a later hour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Mr G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation before the House is an integral part of new initiatives of the Government for the airline industry in Australia. It reflects a desire to increase real competition, give more consumer choice, and make the airline industry more efficient. The legislation permits the Treasurer (Mr Howard) to furnish guarantees for borrowings of $US490m by Ansett Transport Industries and sets out conditions of the guarantees. It is a step towards real competition because the frontline fleets of Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans-Australia Airlines will be different for the first time. We should remind ourselves of the fact that previously competition was illusory based largely on advertising.

SPEECH.PARA: Ansett will completely restructure its fleet. The Airlines Equipment (Loan Guarantee) Bill deals with 21 of those new aircraft-12 Boeing 737 jets, five Boeing 767 wide-bodied aircraft, and four Boeing 727 long-range jets. It is important to put this Bill into perspective with other aviation commitments of the Government, because it represents an addition to a series of important decisions from studies undertaken by the Government, the first being the Domestic Air Transport Policy Review of 1978-79. That review set out the principles and administration of air transport policy. Its recommendations urged more competition in industry, for example, the lessening of parallel scheduling and competition on Australian routes by smaller operators.

Secondly, the Bureau of Transport Economics reviewed general aviation in 1979-80. The BTE examined the structure and the operational and economic characteristics of the general aviation industry. The recommendations of its report must be read in conjunction with the overall air transport policies now developed by the Government. Thirdly, we have the report of the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares in 1980-81. Three main findings were identified in the Holcroft report. They were: An iniquitous cross-subsidisation on fares, a deficient air fare setting formula, and a lack of accountability by the Department of Transport and the airlines. These three reports collated and analysed the views of Ansett, TAA, regional operators, State governments, travel agents and many others with interests in the aviation field.

Consumer demands and expectations were identified by the Holcroft inquiry as being: Firstly, a wider consumer choice, not just in flight service but a real choice in timetables and an end to parallel scheduling; secondly, fairer air fares and the elimination of cross-subsidisation; thirdly, the consumer demand of no compromise on safety; and fourthly, an acknowledgement of the high comparative standards of air services in Australia. Consumers want wider choice. The new generation aircraft to be introduced by Ansett and TAA offer a number of benefits. There will be a real prospect of an end to parallel scheduling which the Holcroft inquiry identified as a major aggravation to the travelling public. Differing capacities of the Airbus and Ansett's Boeings inevitably will require differing schedules. The second advantage is improved fuel efficiency which can be achieved by the new generation aircraft. In view of the fact that fuel costs are now so important in determining overall airline costs, the introduction of fuel-efficient aircraft is to be encouraged.

These developments may not be an unmixed blessing. We need to maintain pressure on the airlines to ensure that new aircraft are not used in ways which disadvantage some routes. Again, it is the travellers on the long haul routes from the extremities of the national network who could be disadvantaged. Large capacity aircraft operating to and from Darwin could mean reduced frequency flights. This would be undesirable unless it permitted a much better service, for example, significant cuts in fares. While curfews remain in place in southern airports, reduced frequencies would leave Darwin only with night flights. Clearly, any movement by the airlines to initiate less frequent services would be opposed by the Northern Territory Government.

It is important to look at the Government's recent response to these events. There have been the move towards elimination of cross-subsidisation and the acceptance of the principles of the Holcroft formula, the announcement of a further investigation and a review of the fares and the methodology adopted by Holcroft, the establishment of a tribunal to hear and to make decisions on future proposals for changes to air fares, and the decision that TAA is to become a public company to enable it to compete better and to be more commercial. The nature of that company, of course, is still to be determined. It appears to me that a number of people are making dangerous presumptions as to how the structure of that company will be set up in the future.

The Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) has announced an inquiry into deregulation of the industry. Of course, this Airlines Equipment (Loan Guarantee) Bill will result in increased competition. The financial guarantees are part and parcel of the existing airlines agreement. Obviously they are essential if Ansett is to obtain new generation aircraft. Approval should be given on the clear understanding that the fundamental reappraisal of the airline industry, which the Government has now foreshadowed, will be carried through. Issues which could be tied to the approval of financial guarantees include the proper examination of air fares and the implementation of the Holcroft recommendations-that is, genuine cuts in fares for long-distance travellers-the follow through by the Government on recent announcements made by the Minister of the inquiry into deregulation of the airline industry; and a review of the two-airline policy. In essence Ansett's need for financial guarantees has provided an opportunity to confirm the Government's commitment to total review of the airline industry, along the lines of the Holcroft report, and deregulation.

It is important to note the difference of approach between the Government and the Opposition. It is one of basic philosophy. Labor's stance is unequivocally socialist and its greatest socialist exponent, the shadow spokesman for Transport, the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Morris) when talking about the TAA options, said that the next Labor government will restore TAA to rightful public ownership. There was no acknowledgment of benefits of present decisions for the industry or for the travelling public. There was just a single-minded concept of keeping it just as it was. There was no desire for the industry to become competitive or efficient; there was just an obsession with restricting TAA's growth and progress and maintaining absolute government control. The Opposition's spokesman on transport stated initially that the Opposition has traditionally supported loan guarantee Bills. In the past, the Australian Labor Party has also supported the two airlines agreement. The political cussedness of now opposing or stalling this legislation is only to allow the Labor Party to make scurrilous accusations against the Government, just because the Government is seeking now to give to Ansett a loan guarantee which has always been available to both Ansett and TAA and which they have had to have to raise money to purchase new aircraft and new equipment.

It is very interesting to look back at the only occasion during the Whitlam Administration when a loan guarantee Bill came before this House. The then Minister for Transport-the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Charles Jones)-said on 17 October 1974:
. . . I expect the Australian airlines to provide the community with the most suitable modern aircraft types. Hence, I look forward to the earlier practicable introduction of wide-bodied jets . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—The honourable member for Newcastle. It is a pity that a few of his colleagues cannot live up to that promise. The Opposition spokesman mentioned the Eximbank loan. He seems to have a strange in-built suspicion when he looks at this matter. The negotiations of those loans is a matter for consideration, I think, by the travelling public, the fare-paying public. They were certainly negotiated at very generous interest rates. The consequential effect has to affect the fare paying public. What did the Opposition's spokesman say? He said that perhaps they could be cancelled, reduced or endorsed by the American authorities or by the bank. He did not mention that the rate could be or almost probably would be increased.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Labor Party should welcome the initiative on these 21 aircraft and the introduction of TAA's Airbus. It is in the interests of the fare paying public and the fares that the public will have to pay. The introduction of the new generation aircraft during the 1980s will be the most exciting event for decades in the domestic aviation industry. Let us remind ourselves that the new aircraft will be more fuel efficient, will be more efficient, operationally, will have higher capacities and will be less noisy-all significant points that should be considered.

TALK.START.PARA: —How will the Territorians benefit?

—If the honourable member waits a minute he will find out. It is also important to recognise that the introduction of these new aircraft will help to stabilise air fares, particularly in comparison with average weekly earnings throughout Australia, making it possible for more people at lower income levels to use this fast, safe and comfortable mode of transport.

SPEECH.PARA: The ALP's stand on this issue causes me to wonder about links with some of its other party objectives. I am suspicious naturally about the impact of the campaign for the 35-hour week. The ALP shows its total disregard for industry and for Australians by seeking to destroy the economic growth achieved so far. Let us relate that 35-hour week to the operations of the transport industry. It is interesting to note the stance at the moment of the militant unions in the Territory with regard to the export and transport of mining products. They threatened to renege on the uranium contracts, just like the ALP is now threatening to renege on a major loan guarantee and on TAA. That can only be described as being totally irresponsible. It can only inject confusion and a lack of confidence into the economy, scaring off investment, as occurred between 1972 and 1975 when confidence was at an all-time low. Is the ALP concoction of a massive public sector propped up by little innovation all that Australians can look forward to under a Labor government?

There has been discussion of the ALP's stance on TAA and the move for it to become more commercial and to be set up as a public operation. Who is worried? Only the fear-mongers. I have had the opportunity to know personally many of the TAA staff. I do not find them all that frightened. The arguments in this debate have centred to a large degree on long haul and short haul air fares. Mr Holcroft certainly addressed himself to this matter. In his inquiry there was a correction of past sins. Northern Territory and Western Australian travellers should not subsidise others. Air fares should be more appropriate and fairer. Time-tabling and services should be better, particularly with the new aircraft being provided by this Bill. The intolerable situation of extra flights at peak holidays periods being scheduled during the night to reach the eastern States for the daytime trade is something that we will probably be able to correct. The time is ripe to stop sweetheart deals between the airlines. It is particularly important to Territorians who have to travel long distances. SPEECH.PARA: I guess that if, in five years time, anything is produced fruitfully the best title would be: 'A major study in still life'. It is as exciting and productive as watching paint dry. Yesterday I announced that the Government has taken an in-principle decision to establish TAA as a public company . . .

But my impression in the election campaign was that you promised that TAA would not be sold. Was my understanding wrong?

Do you think it is fair to make a promise in an election campaign and then to say, five months later, we have changed our mind?
The Prime Minister replied:
I think if circumstance is different, governments have to adjust to that. Yes, I do.
He was asked:
Is there any value in promises in elections?
The reply was:
A great deal, but look. This wasn't a matter of the high point of people's minds at that time. I think you would conceded that also.
The question was then asked:
It was an issue, though, in the campaign.
The Prime Minister replied:
I wouldn't have thought so.

Two things should be mentioned as a result of that interview. The first is that it ceased to be an issue because the Prime Minister gave his word. Most people believe the Prime Minister because of the office he holds. Most people do not know him. If they had known him most people would not have believed his word. The second point is that the Prime Minister said that circumstances had changed. I put the question: In what way? The only change that one can objectively establish as having occurred since the election is, in fact, that the election is out of the way. We all remember his words in 1975: 'We will maintain Medibank'. We know what happened to Medibank. We all recall in 1977: 'Inflation at an annual rate of 5 per cent is within our reach by mid-1979'. By mid-1979 it was 10 per cent, double the rate promised. We recall vividly the promise made in 1975: 'We stand by our commitment to abolish the means test on pensions'. Absolutely nothing has been done since then. We can call to mind the promise made in 1975: 'Petrol prices in all country areas will be reduced to within 1c a litre of the normal city retail price'. We can recall the promises regarding taxes, interest rates and indexation.

The promise that TAA will not be sold is the latest of a long list of promises, solemly given and just as easily broken. The question that must be raised is: Why suddenly has TAA become a liability? We hear a great deal of caterwauling from members of the Government that TAA is under capitalised, too highly geared and that the debt liability is such that repayments on interest and capital will accumulate to a level with new borrowings, that TAA will no longer be a viable commercial enterprise, whatever the word 'viable' happens to mean. TALK.START.PARA: —I make my first and very important point-that TAA has been ripped off by this conservative Government and, it having been ripped off and disabled to that extent, this conservative Government now condemns TAA for the failures that have been created, to the extent that they have been, by the Government's policies. What do the Government's advisers think about all of this? I make a distinction between what the Government's advisers think and what the Minister thinks. What the Minister thinks can be written on the back of a used postage stamp with a crowbar, with some space to spare. One presumes that, if the Minister has read what the advisers think, he does not comprehend it. To be more charitable, probably he does not even read.
—Charity would not enter your heart.
—I recognise that in political terms the Minister is dyslectic-he is a slow reader.
—Really pathetic; it is about time you got a bit of charity in your heart.
—I know how pathetic it is, because I am going to read the pathos on page 19 of a report of the Interdepartmental Committee on TAA's operations which is dated 14 March 1980. Paragraph 39 states:

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, given the Government's support (both explicit by way of guarantee for borrowing and implicit as the owner of TAA) TAA should be able to operate without any equity capital in much the same way as do ATC and APC, borrowing funds as required on the capital market.

That is a crucial proposition. The Government's advisers are saying that all governments, regardless of their political colour, have treated TAA in exactly the same way as they have treated other public sector undertakings such as Telecom Australia and the Australian Postal Commission. That is totally different from the way in which commercial enterprise is treated. Therefore, if TAA, in common with other public sector utilities, should get into what could be described as financial difficulties when measured against private sector commercial undertakings, they arise not because of the efficiency, efficacy or capability of the organisation-the way in which it is run-but rather because of the way in which, conceptually, government has conducted its affairs. The second matter arises in paragraph 40 of the IDC report, which states:

The Committee found that it was unable to determine the extent of Ansett's equity in its airline operations. It noted, however, that both TAA and Ansett have borrowed to the maximum extent possible in their recent aircraft acquisitions. Therefore, the Committee was unable to reach any definitive conclusion on the extent, if any, to which the relative undercapitalisation of TAA provides an advantage over Ansett.

The significance of that is simply that it is impossible for anyone to assert with any claim to honesty and confidence that TAA operates more or less efficiently or successfully than Ansett, or vice versa. The Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares made that clear. Ansett just does not provide information to the Government. This supine individual opposite, the Minister for Transport, who intellectually is too opaque to understand this problem, allows Ansett to walk over the top of him. That is the problem. Is TAA in trouble? It is claimed that Ansett, as a private sector operation, provides better performance and that TAA is excessively geared, it is undercapitalised. It is true that TAA's gearing rate is about 85 per cent, which is high by the standards of comparable industry, which run at about 60 per cent. But, Ansett's rate is in excess of 75 per cent. Honourable members should bear in mind that no one really knows what Ansett's gearing rate is, least of all the Government which has authority under the regulations available to it to demand that Ansett should declare that rate. I put this as another fact to indicate the spuriousness of the case that conservative spokesmen on the other side of this House and more especially in the other chamber-I instance Senator Rae-are seeking to establish, to demolish TAA. The Government has bled TAA white. At the same time time that the Government condemns TAA for being undercapitalised and when it is facing major capital expenditure over the next five years, the Government is seeking a significant increase in dividends. It is a policy of plundering and disposal. It is a crippling rapaciousness of a so-called businessman's government which is run by hobby farmers. I quote again from page 12 of the IDC report. Paragraph 17 states:
Applications of profits to dividends and reserves are subject to approval by the Ministers for Finance and Transport after the operating results for the year are known.
I might go along with one Minister, but would anyone go along with this Minister for Transport? In paragraph 18 the report states:
In recent years--
Listen to this-
decisions on these matters have been taken having a greater regard for the Government's overall budget strategy than TAA's commercial views.

The Government has been ripping it off; it has not given a damn about the profitability of TAA in a so-called commercial environment. I return to page 1 and the summary of that interdepartmental committee report. I do not think anyone on this side of the House, and very few honourable members on the other side of the House, would dispute that the Government's advisers, for all their shortcomings, would know more about this subject than the Minister. The Committee found that TAA's commercial performance has not been as good as Ansetts.
That is fine. It continues:

In this regard the Committee noted, however, a number of commercial disadvantages relating to ground staff superannuation, capitalised exchange losses and operation of uneconomic western Queensland F27 services which reduced the level of TAA's profit.
That is, there is a far greater extent of government induced disabilities than is the case with Ansett. The report goes on:
It was found that TAA's debt/equity (gearing) ratio was high by commercial standards but given TAA's statutory authority status and the protected nature of the industry, it may not be inappropriate.

In other words, the committee is rebuffing the Minister and the Government. It is telling them it is a spurious argument to discover suddenly that TAA is not commercially viable and cannot stand on its own two feet in terms of private sector accounting, because the Government has never required it. All governments have created successively a situation in which TAA has operated on different tours to Ansett. It is completely unfair suddenly to argue that, comparing unlikes, TAA does not perform as well.

I refer to the dimensions of those disabilities. Superannuation alone disadvantages TAA by $2m a year; the uneconomic routes of the F27 aircraft disadvantage TAA by at least $3m a year and the currency revaluation on a borrowing in Swiss francs imposed on TAA against its wishes 11 years ago and, in consequence, subsequent revaluations, forced a write-off of $23m last year. What this all boils down to, very simply, is that a very heavy penalty is borne by TAA as a public enterprise. The remarkable outcome is that in spite of all these things TAA still performs creditably. The dividends which are paid to the Government by TAA are set by the Minister. The dividends that Qantas pays are set by the directors. There is no requirement for the Australian Industry Development Corporation to pay a dividend. I return to page one of the summary of the IDC report. It is very handy to be able to point out to the Government the sort of advice it is receiving upon which it bases its policy decision making. The report states:
However, the Committee concluded it was not possible to make Trans-Australia Airlines fully commercial whilst the Government was a majority shareholder.

That is a particularly significant statement. What it means is that the Government, having embarked on the course which it has rather vaguely described and allowing for the criticisms it is making about TAA's not being commercially viable, being under-capitalised and excessively geared, clearly intends to sell out, at the very least, a majority control of TAA. I warn the Government that we will not bear that. Even if TAA is sold out in that fashion the sorts of defects I have outlined will still have to be repaired. Even as a commercial enterprise, those defects will have to be repaired before TAA can become viable. Paragraph 64 on page 25 of the IDC report states:

The Committee noted that before commercial profits could be achieved resolution of difficulties relating to TAA's groundstaff superannuation, and uneconomic Western Queensland services would be required.

What it boils down to is that the Government ought to have enough guts to face up to the difficulties it has created for TAA, resolve them and allow TAA to get on with the job of providing a proper, adequate and efficient service in the community, unhindered by incompetent government and even more incompetent ministerial administration. I serve fair warning on the Government that the Labor Party, when it is returned to office in 1983, will take immediate steps to ensure that TAA is returned fully to the public sector. We have no embarrassment at all about our ideological commitment to public sector enterprise which can function successfully in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the beginning of a big vendetta against public enterprise. Today the target is TAA. SPEECH.PARA: We are talking this evening about the consumer in Australia.
