Admittedly an investigation is being held by a United States Senate committee. I think we should point out that this is not the first time that Eximbank has given a loan to an Australian airline. It has been going on for donkeys years. It has never been questioned before. If honourable members look at the United States Senate proposal and at what is being investigated they will find that only a small clause is under consideration. That clause concerns services and back-up equipment. There is really no question about the nature of the loan. Allegations which might be made about the impropriety of Mr Rupert Murdoch or ex-President Carter have been denied. Is ex-President Carter now denying, in the face of everyone, that there was no funny business? Is the implication of the shadow Minister for Transport that ex-President Carter is a liar? That would seem to me to be the argument that was put up tonight. That does not come into question.

The only section that is being looked at by the United States Senate committee is that dealing with contingencies. As I said, these are not the first loans that have been lined up in this manner. This has been going on for years. The Australian travelling public is benefiting from loans like these. They are in a most acceptable form. The interest rates are a couple of points lower than they would normally be. If we go on to an open market with higher interest rates only one thing happens: The extra costs will be passed on to the travelling public. Once again the Australian travelling public will be ripped off.

I said earlier that the implications of this Bill are massive. It is interesting that it is only now that the Opposition opposes what has been happening. Only 12 months ago Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans-Australia Airlines decided to go their separate ways. For the first time since the introduction of the two-airline policy we saw in Australia a decision to go into different aircraft types. TAA went off on its Airbus exercise and Ansett went off on its Boeing exercise. That decision made by the two airlines was the first chink in the armour of the two-airline policy because, for the first time, the whole situation of freedom of choice came into play. I am not to say whether TAA made the right decision or whether Ansett made the right decision. We can no longer look successfully towards parallel scheduling of our airline services. It just does not work that way. No longer can the airlines get together, along with the Department of Transport, behind closed doors and under secretive conditions and decide exactly what fares will be because one cannot cost an airline fare by comparing an Airbus with a Boeing 767, or by comparing a Boeing 737 with a souped-up DC9. That sort of thing can no longer occur.

The plain facts of the situation-despite all the reasons that were given by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) tonight-are simply these: No longer can we have the situation that existed in the past, especially in terms of the problems in the structure of TAA, where fares were set along the cost structures of the least efficient carrier, and rightly or wrongly, that happens to be TAA. Now we have an opportunity to get the whole fare structure into perspective. I think that one of the most magnificent moves that has been made by the Government-I include the Ministry and the back bench in my comments because it has been a combined effort-is that for the first time an independent authority will hear, consider and question evidence about airline charges. In this way we can have a little honesty in the airline business.

TALK.START.PARA: —To give the passenger a fair go.

—Yes. I think the Minister should be congratulated. That is what the whole matter is about. I repeat: It is about giving the travelling public a fair go for the first time. Once that is established we can reach a situation where there will be a real input. Perhaps a basic fare can be set and we will be able to go along to the airlines and say: 'It is up to you now. You decide what your economy fare will be and you decide what your super advance purchase excursion fares will be. If you want to run honeymoon specials up to Hayman Island you can go ahead and set a fare even if the aircraft does leave at 11 p.m.'. That is what it is all about.

SPEECH.PARA: The history of overseas aviation, especially in Europe, Great Britain and the United States in the last few years shows that incredible advances have been made. Although conditions are different in Australia-we have obligations to people in the outlying areas and we have thin routes-we now are setting ourselves up so that we can be in a position where we can make reasonable and promotional fares available to all consumers. That is very important.

Let us examine the situation in the United States at the moment. The fact that Australian air fares are about the same price as air fares in the United States and slightly cheaper than the air fares in Europe is quoted often. I do not deny that in relation to scheduled fares. In the United States at the moment about two-thirds of the number of people travelling on airlines are doing so on some sort of discounted fare. The fact that the United States has loosened up its regime has allowed people to experiment with fares, capacity and special flights at all times of the day and night. We have seen a massive increase in the number of people who are using air services. In the United Kingdom and Europe, which also have opened up the system, many of the fares, particularly those around Europe, are being offered at promotional prices-at about 50 per cent of the present levels. I can see no reason why we cannot eventually achieve something like this on the jet routes of Australia. Unless we go down the road that is being promoted by the Minister for Transport at the moment, we are never going to get to a stage where we can provide this sort of promotional fare.

The Leader of the Opposition made very great play of the situation within the structure of TAA where, in fact, it loses many millions of dollars on its Fokker Friendship routes. I am not denying that. Providing those services for the west has been a terrible problem. What we have to try to imagine in our minds now is a completely different system from the one we have ever known. The moves that have been made by the Government simply do this: They establish Ansett and TAA for a period of five years and five years only as the major trunk carriers. An opportunity will be given for third level operators, for commuter operators and for new operators in the airline industry to go in and highly specialise their services.

The proof is already there that Ansett and TAA are not specialist F27 operators. Let us look at an operation like East-West Airlines Ltd in New South Wales. It gives its whole operation to F27s. I believe that East-West Airlines is, indeed, one of the most innovative and one of the most progressive airlines in Australia. It has proved that it can be that way purely because of the fact that it has specialised. I have no doubts that Ansett and TAA will specialise in the jet routes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hazelton.

—Hazelton is another one. The right honourable member for Lowe brings to mind Hazelton. That is a commuter operator that is doing very well indeed. Another example is Bush Pilots Airways Ltd in Queensland which is emerging possibly as the No. 3 airline in Australia. With this sort of innovation it will have an opportunity not only to get into those routes that are thin in their nature but, indeed, to get into some of the cream routes that are presently being operated by Ansett and TAA with those smaller aircraft. This is the exciting concept of the road that the Government is going down at the moment. This is what the Government should be congratulated for. It will ultimately be horses for courses. When we get down that road, I do not deny that there will be quite a big upheaval in many of the air services. If we can look down the road five to eight years ahead, I can see an exciting time for Australia when, not only will so many of these remote areas be serviced and some of these country towns getting just one service a day, but also many services a day. One can do this on a horses for courses basis even with aircraft.
—And get the right equipment.

—The Minister has said that they must get the right equipment. He, of course, is perfectly correct. That is exactly what will emerge and that is exactly what will happen. If one looks at the United States experience, there are some tremendous examples there where airline operators as big as United Air Lines have been forced to pull out of some of the smaller routes. Certainly in the south of the United States, Texas International Airlines is one example that comes to mind, of a company that has done very well indeed. United pulled out of a lot of those routes and Texas International went in there operating specialised equipment. It was not a case of towns losing services. In fact, where it had one service a day, which was not terribly profitable, it now has three, four, five and up to eight services a day using smaller specialised equipment and those services are highly profitable. That is what it is all about.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen that sort of example emerge in my own State of Queensland. Let us look at the Bush Pilots operation to a place like Emerald. Emerald did not have any air services at all. Bush Pilots Airways went in with its Metroliner. It was a specialised type of aircraft and from a situation of no air services Emerald at the moment has up to four flights a day. That is a very profitable route. One has the same situation in Thangool and at Dysart. I am not sure, but I do not think the population of Emerald would be more than five or six thousand. This is the type of development that will happen and we must encourage it.

The other matter I want to talk about is the inquiry into deregulation. Although I have stood up in this House quite often and advocated a form of deregulation in Australia, I do not profess to be the greatest expert on it. I believe that there must be a very close examination of all the ramifications and all the implications of deregulation. It does the people of Australia no good to have State transport Ministers within 24 hours of statements being made in this House appearing in the Press around Australia and blasting all hell out of this Minister and this Government when those Ministers do not have a clue in the world what is going on and they do not know what it is all about. We have seen examples of this attitude in the last weekend. Indeed, the State Ministers will be condemned out of their own mouths by the time they settle down and have a look at the long term implications of this proposal. It extends beyond that. It extends to a lot of the mayors in some of these remote areas. I make this plea to them: Just keep your mouths shut for a while, fellows, if you possibly can; sit down and study the ramifications and implications and I am sure that you will agree in the long term Australia is headed towards a situation where we will have proper airline services to all points within the country, where we will have a fair, reasonable, equitable--

TALK.START.PARA: —Cheaper.

—As the honourable member for Perth says, we will have a cheaper airline service all round Australia. I know that the Minister is interested too in terms of international aviation. I believe that this particular move initially to establish the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares ultimately can probably be extended to international air fares as well. I have spoken to the Minister and I know of his particular interest in this matter. I remember one night we were discussing a newspaper advertisement that appeared in the Sunday Observer in London a couple of weeks ago. The Minister and I were surprised to learn that fares from London to Australia were openly being advertised for #198 one-way, which is not bad, being about one-third of the price of the going fares operating out of Australia at the moment. I think that that is probably an example of what free market forces do. Maybe there is an option there to go into some form of deregulation, it need not be complete deregulation and, indeed, in international terms it is probably hard to go into a full deregulation situation in a country like Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Ultimately we will have to look at some sort of capacity control in Australia, but the opportunity is there to extend these cheaper air services into the international sphere. That, of course, achieves two purposes. It does that which I mentioned earlier in my speech tonight; it provides a much more fair, equitable and cheaper air service to Australians and it makes Australia a much more equitable proposition for international tourists.

So, all in all, I think I should repeat that this is the very beginning of going down what will be a long road until we really get the whole airline industry into place. We are going into a situation where there will be some upheavals and there will be a number of changes in terms of domestic aviation as we know it in Australia. We know that the present fare setting policy at last is on a fair basis. Although there have been some rather major increases on some routes, the situation we have achieved initially is that we have a fair and equitable system and that has to get into line. We have to get to a situation where we can get ourselves a standard kilometre rate. That, in itself, will make some adjustments to the fares and some of the fares will go down.

We have reached a stage where no longer is the subsidisation going from the long distance passengers to the short haul passengers; and that is important. We have set that point in principle, but we have a bit further to go down the road. At last we are taking aviation into a public forum where people know what is going on and have an opportunity to make some sort of input into the type of air services that they want. We are getting to a stage where there will be true competition because of different types of aircraft, because of the different costs of aircraft and because of different timetables that we have not had for the last 24 years. It is terribly important to give people that freedom of choice. Once we get TAA established as a fully viable operation that can go into competition with Ansett, I am sure one will see the free market forces come into play and, indeed, the entrepreneurial nature of Trans-Australia Airlines comes to the fore. One will see the deals coming up, the promotion of special flights and the promotion of domestic Australian destinations and that can only be for the good of all Australians.

Finally, I repeat the proposition that Australians enjoy all the basic human freedoms except one, until the moves that have been made by this Minister, by this Government and all the members of the Government, and that human freedom was the freedom to fly at the right price; but we are getting it now. Really, that is what it is all about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon C.K.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Deputy Speaker, chairmanship of the House of Representatives Select Committee on Tourism helped the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Jull) in one respect; that was to at least teach him something about what happens in tourism and aviation. Whilst I do not always agree with what he has to say in a debate on airlines and all that goes with it, at least he puts up some points of view that require an answer. In his concluding remarks the honourable member for Bowman talked about the two-airline policy. Which government was responsible for setting up that closed door type of industry? Which government created the two-airline agreement? Perhaps we should call it the Ansett agreement as the agreement was set up so that the Ansett organisation could go on printing money; that is what it amounts to. It was created by the Liberal-Country party Government of the Menzies era and it carried through until the Australian Labor Party was voted into government in 1972. In fact, the agreement was tied up so tightly that the Labor Government could not shift it. Let us face the facts of life. It was so tied up that it could not be shifted. The reason why it is being shifted today is that the Government is about to make it even better for Ansett than it is at present. That is the only reason why there will be a renegotiation of the agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Bowman talked about the public getting a fair go. Which political parties stopped Trans-Australia Airlines from operating in Western Australia? It was done by the Liberal-Country party coalition. The then Opposition in this place used its numbers in the other place to stop the appropriate amendments, in the form of the airlines legislation that we put forward in 1973, from going through. Those parties are responsible for the people of Western Australia not getting a 25 per cent cut in the price of airline fares. I say to the honourable member for Bowman that it is easy to make such comments, but for God's sake have regard to the facts.

The allegedly terrible Whitlam Government introduced off-peak fares in the face of opposition from Ansett. Before that Liberal Ministers for Transport would not allow off-peak air fares to be brought in. When we came into government we gave instructions to the then Chairman of TAA, Sir Frederick Scherger, who completely and totally supported the concept of off-peak travel, to tell the other fellow-Sir Reginald Ansett is known in aviation circles as the other fellow-that TAA would be introducing off-peak fares from a particular date and that if he did not like them he could stay out of it. He had enough brains to come into it. One thing I will say about Sir Reginald Ansett is that when one has a fight with him one has a fight on one's hands, but he is a bloke who relaxes and enjoys it when he knows that something is inevitable.

I was interested in the comments of the honourable member for Bowman regarding East-West Airlines. It is a good airline and it should be given the opportunity of exploiting and expanding quite a number of the air routes in Australia. If it does set up a decent route and expands it, Trans-Australia Airlines and Ansett should be stopped from moving in and taking it over, as has happened on occasions. As far as the comments of the honourable member on the light aircraft flown in Queensland are concerned, Trans-Australia Airlines should be permitted to abandon the unprofitable F27 flights that it is compelled to operate in Queensland. Let me cite my own district as an example. When F27 aircraft operated between Newcastle and Sydney, there was one flight out of a morning and one flight in of an afternoon. A fellow by the name of Keith Hilder, with great imagination and initiative, attacked the problem by introducing light aircraft-Cessna 402 aircraft-with the result that today there are 24 flights a day each way between Newcastle and Sydney. There are more aircraft flying between Newcastle and Sydney than there are buses in some of the suburbs of Newcastle. These things should be looked at. When the Government of Queensland says that we have to retain F27 aircraft it is doing the people of western Queensland a disservice. I honestly believe that with the appropriate selective type of light aircraft they will get a much better service than they have presently.

The legislation we are dealing with is the Airlines Equipment (Loan Guarantee) Bill, which deals with a guarantee by this Parliament of loans totalling some $490m for Ansett Transport Industries Ltd to enable it to buy 21 Boeing aircraft. I join the honourable member for Bowman on the score that this is another step into the field of genuine competition between the two main trunk route operators. Trans-Australia Airlines opted for the A300 aircraft, which I believe is a very good aircraft. It is highly suited for the work that it will be required to do in Australia, as are the aircraft that Ansett is proposing to buy. The Boeing Corporation is one of the best aircraft manufacturers in the world today. That has been proven by the performance of the aircraft that that company has manufactured. So for the first time we will have a degree of competition.

Years ago when Trans-Australia Airlines wanted to buy Caravelle aircraft, which likewise have proven themselves, it was refused permission to do so by the Menzies Government. We were stuck then with the aircraft that Ansett wanted. The same thing happened with the purchase of the DC6B aircraft for Ansett. Trans-Australia Airlines bought Viscounts. The Viscounts proved to be a better aircraft and a better proposition all told. They were more popular with the people and more economical. The result was that the Menzies Government forced Trans-Australia Airlines to exchange aircraft. Honourable members opposite talk about the policies of socialist parties. That was a case of socialising the losses and capitalising the gains to the advantage of Ansett. When Ansett makes a mistake the Liberal Government rectifies it. We are now at the stage where we will at least have a choice of aircraft. We may not have a choice as to departure and arrival times, but at least we will have a choice of aircraft on which to travel. The decision to purchase the five A300 aircraft and the 21 aircraft that Ansett is buying-a number of which are wide-bodied aircraft-should have been taken six years ago when the Labor Government was in office.

In 1974-75 the opinion of the airlines was sought as to the earliest date they could introduce wide-bodied aircraft. Ansett opposed the introduction of wide-bodied aircraft. The man was opposed to every damn thing that was a change. He was frightened of a real change. So he opposed it. By the time we reached some point with it we were unfortunately disposed of by a representative of the Central Intelligence Agency in Australia, the then Governor-General. This Government has done nothing about that in the intervening period. These aircraft would have provided more economic operations within Australia. They are quieter aircraft. Everything to do with these wide-bodied aircraft was preferable to the aircraft then in use in Australia. This Government has plenty to answer for. If the Labor Government had remained in office the result would have been much different. Wide-bodied aircraft would have been operating in Australia at least five years ago.

It is interesting to see this matter being brought forward at this stage. It is pretty obvious that the back bench members who thought that they had the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) by the scruff of the neck have been outsmarted. He has outsmarted them again, just as he has outsmarted the rest of the electorate over the years by making all sorts of promises and breaking them. A promise does not mean a thing to him. He breaks them as quick as lightning. This is another one that he will break. The back bench members will be double-crossed because once this Bill goes through the Parliament there will be nothing they can do about all the other pressures they have been talking about applying to the Prime Minister; the opportunity will be gone. Having in mind that these aircraft will be delivered in 1985, 1986, 1987 and 1988, this legislation should be brought in to cover the aircraft as they are being delivered to Ansett or Trans-Australia Airlines as the case may be.

One other matter I want to refer to is the question of interest. When we were in government we told the public what interest rates had to be paid on Eximbank loans. A few years ago-I think it was on 14 November 1978-when we last dealt with an airlines equipment Bill, I endeavoured to squeeze out of the then Minister for Transport-the present Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon)-details of the interest rates. He could not give them to us. The information was commercial. The airlines were the only ones entitled to know. The interest rates that Ansett were paying were not something to be spread all over the world.

I have looked very closely on this occasion to ascertain the interest rates that Ansett is to pay. I read every word in the Minister's second reading speech. I assumed that this information was top secret and confidential and that it could not be released. The only way that I could find out what the interest rates were was to read the American Press. Cuttings from the American Press indicate that the interest rates are 8 per cent and 8.4 per cent. Why does not the Minister come into this place and tell the Parliament all the facts? Why does he not give us the details of what the interest rates are? This should not be a private matter. It involves this Parliament and it involves the people of Australia. The people of Australia are entitled to know. I hope that the Minister will learn a lesson. In fact this will be the last occasion on which he will be in charge of an airlines equipment Bill because aircraft will not be purchased for another three years. The honourable member for Shortland (Mr Morris) will be the next Minister to introduce an airlines equipment Bill.

One of the things that concerns me is the fact that we have no real control over the operations of Ansett. Sure, Ansett can come along each year and give us a piece of paper which purports to be a correct report of its operations. That is all we can get. It took me a long time as the shadow Minister for Transport in this place to force the government of the day into the position of requiring Ansett at least to give us that piece of paper. It was not so many years ago that the only information one could get on Ansett was the total financial report which it circulated publicly every 12 months. But at least we have that. As the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) said tonight, we do not know the internal workings of Ansett. We do not know what capital is invested in the airline. We do not know on what basis profit is calculated. One of the conditions of the guaranteed equipment loans that are of great financial advantage to Ansett should be that Ansett set up a separate airline, one that has nothing whatever to do with Ansett's road operations, nothing to do with Ansett's television interests and nothing to do with Murdoch's other investments. It should be a straight out airline operation whose activities are wholly and solely associated with aviation.

The same thing should apply as far as TAA is concerned. If TAA wants to go into the hire car business, into tourism or into engineering, that is okay. If it wants to do that it should set up a subsidiary company that will conduct those affairs. But because of the extent of the preferential treatment that the main trunkline operators are getting from this Government the people who are using those airlines are entitled to know that they are not paying 1c per kilometre more than they should be paying. I say to the Minister for Transport who is sitting at the table that the Government should give serious consideration to setting up an airline company that will do the things that I have just outlined. That company should operate only as an airline so that we know what the profits or losses are and what costs are incurred. We should be told about the whole operation of the airlines. We should say: 'To hell with the rest of the things they are doing'. The airline operations of these companies should be separate from other operations. Do not let us get the facts confused. We should require the airlines to declare their company investment, their share- holding and all the rest of it so that at least we can work out the true position.

On 14 September 1978 I made a speech on the last airlines equipment Bill which was Airline Equipment Bill (No. 2). In that speech I drew attention to what was happening at that time. I pointed out that TAA had purchased a number of 727 200 series Boeing aircraft and that it had financed this purchase out of its own money without borrowing from overseas. I further pointed out that Ansett had financed its aircraft purchase out of money that it had got from the Eximbank in the United States. I drew attention then to the fact that Associated Securities Ltd, the finance company, was in a perilous state, and that the money that was being borrowed by Ansett, allegedly for aircraft, was to finish up in ASL. About that time I think $10m was transferred by Ansett to ASL. Aviation money should not be used to bolster up a finance company or a television station as happened in the early days of a Melbourne television station that was owned and is still owned by Ansett. Ansett used money from its airline operations to keep that television station going. We are not interested in that. The two-airline agreement, airfares and all the rest of it involves aviation and not television. That is why I say to the Minister that the Government should require this airline to be a separate private company doing nothing else but aviation.

The debate which is being carried on at present is concerned with the comparative operations of TAA and Ansett. Let us have a look at the reports of these two organisations. For 1979-80 Ansett showed a net operating profit after income tax of $8,008,000. For the same period TAA's profit was $8,702,000. The 1979-80 report of TAA contains a table which covers the company's profits for the last five years. In fact one can go back for at least the last 20 years and one will find that TAA made a profit on every occasion. Why do honourable members opposite want to get rid of an organisation that makes millions of dollars profit year after year? They want to hand it over to their own supporters, the people who finance their election campaigns. That is the real import of the Government's intentions. If TAA were a losing proposition honourable members opposite would not want to touch it and they would not want to take it over at any price.

I would now like to discuss the amendment moved by the honourable member for Shortland and what is behind it. This whole deal involving this loan stinks like hell-like everything that Murdoch touches. This is the man who supported us in the 1972 election. When we would not deliver his crooked goods for him he then turned on us and in 1975 and ever since he has been instrumental in the defeat of the Labor Party and the return of the Liberal-National Country Party coalition. This man is a crook and anything that he is associated with is rotten and stinking. One only has to read the Australian papers to see what happened. A report from America in one paper was headed: 'Anger over Loan to Murdoch'. The article stated:
America's Export-Import Bank should be put out of business because of deals like its controversial loan to Ansett Airlines, an influential financial magazine claims.

This magazine was Barron's the weekly publication of Dow Jones and Co. This is typical of what is happening in America. That report was published on 3 June 1980. I do not have time to go through all the reports in the Australian Press of what is happening in America today. But another article states:

Senator William Proxmire, a Democratic member of the Senate Banking committee, has referred to the General Accounting Office-the investigative arm of Congress-allegations that more than 17 per cent of the loan is for publicity, advertising and other 'extras'.

One can go on. Three of the major organisations of the American Congress are investigating Ansett Transport Industries of Australia. Yet this Government is prepared to guarantee the loan of $490m. Although this company is under close investigation by the Congress of the United States the Government is still prepared to guarantee its loan. This matter should be deferred until this total inquiry has been completed and the people of Australia know whether the loan is fair dinkum or whether it is politically inspired. The history of the loan in the initial stages is that Mr Murdoch had lunch with the then President of the United States of America and three days later the bank came out and gave a most favourable loan-one of the most favourable loans that has been granted by Eximbank over recent years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dean Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I wish to compliment the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Charles Jones) who has just spoken in the debate on much of what he has said. Indeed, most of the time he spoke with a great deal more honesty and a great deal more knowledge than did other Opposition members who contributed to this debate. For example, the honourable member quite correctly referred to the increased competition which will accrue by virtue of the different equipment purchases of the airlines. By and large, until the end of his speech he avoided the baseless excesses of the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Morris) and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden). I only regret that he felt obliged, I suppose for the sake of the Australian Labor Party, to end his speech by repeating some of the anti-Murdoch rubbish which we have heard from Opposition members in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard from Opposition speakers a tirade of unsubstantiated innuendo and scurrilous allegation. To prove that point, I wish to quote from the second reading speech of the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt). He had this to say:

The Australian National Airlines Act already authorises the Treasurer to provide guarantees for TAA's borrowings. This Bill is consistent with the principle of according similar treatment in respect of guarantees to the airlines.

In other words, within the framework of the two-airline agreement-so far I have not heard any objection from Opposition speakers to the two-airline agreement, one presumes that they are quite happy about that-the Government is here providing guarantees to Ansett Airlines of Australia that are available to Trans-Australia Airlines under another Act. Honourable members might ask what is wrong with that. There is nothing wrong with that. Yet we have from the Opposition the allegation that in this Airlines Equipment (Loan Guarantee) Bill the Government is doing more than affording equal treatment. To quote the colourful phrase of the Leader of the Opposition, it is handing out 'to one of the crooks of the commercial world'.

It just shows the Murdoch paranoia of the Leader of the Opposition. It just shows how he is not prepared to debate what this Bill and surrounding issues are all about. He is not prepared to talk about how we are trying to improve the lot of the average traveller in this country. There is none of that. He is simply trying to denigrate by virtue of his own paranoia.

Indeed, there is more than that. Where is the evidence to support the statement that this man Murdoch is 'a crook of the commercial world'? No evidence has been brought foward in this debate. All we have had is baseless allegations and no evidence. The mere fact that some committee in the United States of America is looking at the matter is no evidence of anything being wrong. Yet, because of its paranoia about Murdoch, the Opposition is trying to dredge up this matter and it is trying to suggest, by virtue of this Bill we are passing tonight, which is doing no more than affording similar treatment to that which is already being given to TAA, that there is something unduly wrong. What absolute rubbish!

The Leader of the Opposition said also that TAA carries too much lead in the saddle. Yet significantly he avoided the question of the supperannuation carried by TAA which presumably is part of that lead. If he is going to talk about that, why does he not talk about all of the facts instead of ignoring some of them just to support his own baseless attacks. If TAA is carrying too much lead why is it not, therefore, desirable and reasonable to help TAA's position by forming it into a public company, by inquiring into the two-airline agreement and by inquiring into the possibilities of further airline industry de-regulation?

The true colours of the Leader of the Opposition came through at the end of his speech. He concluded his speech with a general tirade against the private sector of this nation. He talked about private enterprise in this country forever going broke. Yet he did not admit that private enterprise has been the very basis of the growth and development of this nation. He extolled the virtues of public enterprise simply to show up his true socialist colours. One is left to presume that all he was doing, rather than adding factually to the debate on this Bill in the House tonight, was orchestrating a speech for the benefit of his own back bench, helping his own left-wingers to believe that he is still a true socialist. I say to honourable members opposite that if that is the best their leader can do, shame on him.

Three issues emerge from the second reading speech of the Minister to which I should like to refer. Firstly, let us consider briefly the decision to make TAA a public company. That decision quite properly carries with it certain concerns. It carries with it a concern that whatever is the new structure of TAA, that airline and the other major airline, Ansett, should be able to maintain services to this nation which are both reasonable and desirable. It carries with it also the prospect of being able to improve TAA's competitive position. Indeed, it carries with it the possibility that if, for example, the final decision is to make of TAA something like the Qantas type of wholly owned company, TAA may well benefit from this move. In other words, a move is being made to help TAA in its competitive position, so that as further investigations proceed into the airline system in Australia, TAA, along with Ansett, will be in a better position to offer to the Australian public more of what it deserves in future years. Basically, of course, that comes down to more reasonable fares in relative terms.

There is no reason at all why we should not consider a step towards deregulation. I have always been one of those people who are not against the two-airline agreement. After all, in my view it has helped to maintain a very fine safety record in this nation. It has helped to maintain services to many outback parts of the nation; services which, without a two-airline agreement, might not to this point have been developed. Nevertheless, what is wrong with being flexible? What is wrong with considering deregulation which may enable us to build on the foundations thus laid and to provide an even better, more flexible and more reasonable service to many parts of Australia in the future. For this reason I would be one of those people who would applaud the carrying out of an inquiry. Certainly it cannot do any harm to have more knowledge than we have at present. After all, the inquiry into further deregulation will provide us with more knowledge than we have at present. I would applaud that.

The decision on air fares that has been announced by the Government in recent days gives some cause for concern in my State of Queensland. In some respects Queensland can be seen to have done somewhat badly at this time. For example, Queensland has not been seen to have done so well in terms of lower increases in air fares on the long haul routes, and yet it has suffered from the short haul increases we all know about. I recognise, of course, that the current fare structure is an interim one. It is an approach to the Holcroft report and an attempt to provide a formula which in the short term will get over some of the cross-subsidisation which was found to exist by the Holcroft inquiry. Nevertheless, as far as Queensland is concerned, we certainly can hope for improvements in the fare structure of the nation as we know that the Government is going down the track towards working out a better formula. Whilst at present one might be a little suspicious of any benefits to Queensland from the current air fares decision, nevertheless, with the establishment of the independent fare tribunal, with the further working out of the two-airline agreement, and with the inquiry into deregulation upon which the Government has decided, we certainly have moved a distance towards providing for the Australian public and certainly for the people in Queensland a fairer structure of air fares. That can only be applauded. Notwithstanding the interim weaknesses that can be seen in the current air fares decision, the decision to set up the independent fare tribunal, the decision to consider deregulation, the decision to establish TAA as a public company and the decision to support Ansett in its purchase of quite different equipment from that of TAA, which the honourable member for Newcastle has said will add to competition, certainly are great improvements and great steps forward-a product of the events of the last few days. For those reasons I applaud the steps that the Government has taken.

SPEECH.PARA: Somehow, it does not seem to be appropriate to feel terribly sorry for the Minister since, I suppose, one has to assume that he has some responsibility for his actions and the mutations of his position. His record speaks for itself. That has been amply alluded to with great accuracy by members on this side of the House during this debate. I do not think it is particularly appropriate to go over the record again. I do not think-this is one little act of charity-we should be so terribly cruel to the Minister as to drive the barbs in even more deeply than doubtless they are. It is an unpremeditated and truly remarkable example of double standards for the Government to rush in legislation to support the privately owned major airline by guaranteeing the purchase by Ansett Transport Industries Ltd to the order of $US490m when at the same time it is moving to sell out Trans-Australia Airlines supposedly to make it more competitive. That is a non-sequitur if ever I have heard one.

As has been indicated the management of Ansett Airlines has brought its problems upon itself by attempting to curry favour with the United States Administration before and after the election. Surely, while this matter is under investigation by the United States Senate banking committee, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and so on, the management of Ansett deserves no sympathy. Why should Australian money be used to guarantee these greedy men? The acquisition of these new aircraft in such numbers will further increase the advantage that Ansett Transport Industries Ltd has over an undercapitalised TAA. Why did the Government not deal with this issue at the time the purchases were mooted? The Minister claims that his action is even-handed by suggesting that the Australian National Airlines Act authorises the Treasurer to provide guarantees for TAA's borrowings and that it would be equitable to do the same with Ansett. As I said, why this post hoc action? Why was it necessary to take the action proposed by the Government at this stage? It is a typical example of the amoral and the ad hoc volte-face that is so characteristic of this Government.

It is quite remarkable to observe just how insensitive to public reaction this Government really is. It would seem that the electorate of this nation has no right to expect consistency and propriety from this Government. This Government has a fanatical desire to remove itself from ownership of any successful enterprise. It is a fanatical desire; it is not a rational one. The people of Australia should mark well the ominous implications of these moves to hand over TAA to the private sector. Let us just face it. That is where TAA will move inexorably. The peculiar sense of justice that pervades the benches opposite would sell out successful government enterprises to the moguls of commerce and industry after using vast sums of public money, much of it from the taxpayers who cannot buy into the sale of their own property.

We have seen the enormous deluge of crocodile tears from the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Jull) and the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Dean) about our supposed lack of concern for the consumers. Nowhere have we heard anything about the concern for the owners of TAA. That is what we are talking about. What a perfidious government this is! Did the Minister or his Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) tell the electorate during the last election campaign that a plan was afoot to divest the Government, the people of this country-for that is, though the Government might forget it, what the Government is supposed to be about-of its own publicly-owned enterprises? Of course they did not. They never do. These are the afterthoughts. As has been pointed out by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) these are matters which the Prime Minister considers to be miniscule in importance. But we have come to expect that sort of behaviour from the Government.

TAA is a publicly owned enterprise-I am speaking of now, not when it is sold-and the Government is its custodian. Yet the Government and its responsible Minister-I use that in the formal sense-is prepared to disregard the interests of the real owners of this enterprise and proceed to sell it to the select few. That is what will take place. As I said, it is inexorable. The codswallop which we have been treated to that suggests that decisions have not been taken is something which I have come to dismiss. It might seem that I am being rather harsh towards the Minister. To be sure, he has reassured the House that he will not permit the moguls of transport, the proprietors of Ansett Transport Industries Ltd, to obtain control of TAA. We are also treated to the same depth of assurance by the Prime Minister. But, as the Minister would recall, he and also the Prime Minister have gone on record with a reassuring notion that the Government would not sell TAA. There is little doubt that the Minister has caved in to a push of zealots on his own back bench, plus the pressures from outside-perhaps the real government of this country.

The Minister introduced this Bill in such haste-I am sure he would agree that it was done in haste-and at such a late hour to avoid debate. This shows how confused the poor man was. As I have said, the Minister has changed his position, without satisfactory explanation not just to us on the Opposition benches-quite obviously he does not have to give that much to his own back benchers-but to the Australian people and their formal representatives in the Parliament. Why must this House be repeatedly affronted by the temerity of this Minister who has assured us that TAA would not be sold. Now he expects us to accept his assurances that, when sold, it will not fall into the hands of the wealthy backers of this Government. We have no grounds for accepting his assurances-and why should we? What are we to look forward to now? Will the same situation apply as in relation to successful enterprises such as areas of Telecom Australia, Australia Post, the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, et cetera? Institutions that have belonged to the people of this nation and have served them so well must now be seen to be in jeopardy.

Some members of the Government appear to be having a flirtation with the term 'philosophy'. An avalanche of pseudo-philosophical garbage has descended upon the floor of this House, with the frequency and unrecognised occurrence of non sequiturs. The honourable member for Herbert is a classic example of those who use them. Other lapses in logic indicate that many people are merely using the term to give authority to their prejudices and enthusiasms. The naive social and economic stances of so many honourable gentleman opposite are no substitute for rational discourse. The people of this country will judge these men guilty and will catapult them into political oblivion at the next election. The only ones who will applaud them will be the small and select coterie of wealthy manipulators of the stocks and shares whose coffers are already amply filled.

If this Government's actions are endorsed and the over-indulged friends of the Government gain control of TAA it will not be average Australians who will be able to buy back some of their own property. Since 70 per cent of the Australian population earn less than the average weekly earnings, their battle to survive will make the purchase of shares a somewhat irrelevant issue. As 80 per cent of the income earners in my noble electorate of Ballarat earn less than the average weekly earnings, the theft of the airline which they already own will no doubt make them angrier and more cynical of this Government's machinations to offer the wealthy further opportunities to widen the gap between the haves and have-nots in our society. The Government has impugned the integrity of this Parliament. What the Australian people are deserving of is an explanation of the motives of those hell bent on selling off the people's own enterprises. I deplore the simplistic apologies for economic theory that are used so obviously by those in the Government as a crude attempt to justify their belief in economic Darwinism. Given the seriousness of this matter, I endorse the amendment proposed by the honourable member for Shortland. I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I speak on behalf of those consumers whom the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Jull) said Government members were wishing to protect. SPEECH.PARA: The Airlines Equipment (Loan Guarantee) Bill provides a guarantee for loans entered into by Ansett Transport Industries Ltd for the new front line Boeing aircraft. In all, Ansett will acquire 21 Boeing aircraft at an all-up cost in excess of $800m. Last year, the new owner of Ansett, Rupert Murdoch, negotiated a loan for $290m from the Export-Import Bank of America in return for which Jimmy Carter received an editorial endorsement from Mr Murdoch's New York newspaper, the New York Post. Naturally, the loan produced a storm of controversy. Such storms are nothing new for Mr Murdoch. He has caused considerable turbulence in the process of amassing his international empire. In this country, the News Ltd-Ansett network rivals the authority of the Federal Government itself. Rupert Murdoch has more de facto power over the Australian people than the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), Elizabeth II and Joh Bjelke-Petersen combined.

Such a power structure outside the democratic checks and balances of public accountability must be an unhealthy development. Now, having corrupted American politics, having in effect bought a former President with his influence as a Press baron, he is to receive the privileged patronage of the Parliament by gaining our guarantee for this ill-gotten loan. What is up with us in Australia? What an operator the man is. One cannot help but admire his gall. He has more front than a Mack truck. The failing Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) is just another in Rupert's long line of conquests. This legislation ought to be renamed 'Rupert Murdoch's easy-money, fly now pay later Bill'.

The manner in which this legislation was dropped in our laps last week, without notice, moments before the adjournment is entirely appropriate. My colleague, the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Morris), immediately after the introduction of the Bill stated:
Here, at this almost indecent hour the Bill was brought in and thrown away as a throw-away line . . .

The loan itself is surrounded with indecency. The headlines of newspapers in Australia have told the story. I quote a few of them: 'Ansett loan under fire', 'FBI looks at Ansett $290m loan', and 'Anger over loan to Murdoch'. Are we not aware of what has been happening in America? An article under the headline 'Unease at Ansett loan' stated:
Three senior US Senators said yesterday that they were dissatisfied with the US Export-Import Bank's explanation of the generous terms it had offered on a loan to Ansett Airlines.
Another newspaper heading reads: 'Envoy to explain his part in Ansett loan'. The list goes on.

The legislation is not without its humourous side. The Minister has informed us that clause 5 of the Bill provides that the Treasurer must be satisfied that the terms and conditions of the borrowing are reasonable. I ask: Reasonable to whom-to the consumers of Australia, the United States Import-Export Bank or to Rupert Murdoch? Maybe the present Treasurer (Mr Howard) should ask the United States Senate, the Federal Bureau of Investigation or the man himself. The Opposition takes the view, as expressed in the amendment moved by the honourable member for Shortland, that the Government should be satisfied that the terms and conditions of the loan and the manner in which the loan was secured should not only be reasonable but above suspicion. The sinister background against which this Bill has been introduced deserves some comment. The spectre of a wholesale sell-out of the nation's airline Trans-Australia Airlines, hangs over this Parliament. Much has been said about this sell-out. The Minister, in his April Fools' Day statement on domestic air fares, revealed the Government's intentions. He said:

The Government has decided in principle to establish TAA as a public company. The Government has under consideration the nature and structure of such a company. Such an arrangement should enable TAA to compete more effectively in a more commercial environment.

In what is probably an attempt to please the visiting monetarist, Milton Friedman, the Government is clearly paving the way for the sale of TAA. But even the arch-monetarist, as my friend the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Armitage) describes him, had this to say in his book, Capitalism and Freedom-which is itself a non sequitur:
Unregulated monopoly may not be tolerable and either public regulation or ownership may be the lesser evil.
I shall quote just one of the statements that have been made by Government spokesmen on the subject of selling TAA:
The Federal Government had ruled out the sale of TAA to private interests, the Minister for Transport, Mr Nixon, told a meeting of government back benchers yesterday.
Speaking at the weekly meeting of the coalition parties in Canberra, he said there were a thousand political and social reasons why the sale was not acceptable.

This statement has been repeated time and time again, and yet again today in this Parliament, but one would need to have rocks in the head still to believe anything that this Government said. The intention of the Government is now plain. TAA is about to be sold off to the highest bidder and interested speculators can lodge their bids at Liberal Party headquarters in the form of party donations. The Opposition has already made it perfectly clear that the only result of the auctioning of TAA will be the inevitable creation of a private monopoly in the provision of major domestic airline services, with higher air fares and greater profits for Ansett.

TAA has proven itself a success. Obviously, the members of the Liberal and National Country parties like nothing less than a successful government enterprise. Their lauding of TAA this evening shows that it has been successful as a government enterprise. This disproves all their mindless theories about government ownership on behalf of the people. TAA enjoys the support of a majority of Australia's air travellers. Ansett, despite the cheap cheesecake advertising to which it has resorted, and which we have come to expect from Mr Murdoch, is a poor second in a two-airline race. The pre-eminence of TAA is all the more remarkable when consideration is given to the obstacles placed in its path by the Government. TAA has been starved of capital and has been forced to operate with a higher borrowing ratio than has its competition. Last year it was compelled to pay a higher dividend to the Government than was commercially sound. It incurs greater superannuation liabilities than does Ansett because of government directives, and maintains a service on unprofitable inland routes such as those in Queensland. Despite these obstacles, TAA has beaten Ansett hands down. To use these very same government-created obstacles as some pretext for getting rid of TAA is irresponsible and dishonest.

It is equally irresponsible and dishonest for the Government to distort the recommendations of the Holcroft committee and to attempt to use that report as justification for this action. As the honourable member for Shortland has already pointed out, nowhere in any of the 36 recommendations of that inquiry is there any suggestion, or even a word, which recommends or mentions the sale of TAA, or a change in its financial structure.

I am particularly concerned about the implications in the Government's plan for air services in rural Queensland, a subject that has been mentioned earlier this evening. As a Queenslander, I am convinced that rural Queenslanders will feel the brunt of the Government's decision to make TAA a public company. Once it goes public it will be unable to resist the pressure to withdraw from unprofitable country routes. As a public company, the first priority of TAA will be profits rather than service. The Holcroft report concluded that TAA was losing about $11m a year on its Fokker Friendship services. When the profit motive is the main consideration, the re- structured TAA will drop unprofitable routes, such as the Fokker services, as soon as it can. This is bad for Queensland. The Minister for Transport's own party supporters in Queensland recognise this consequence. At the weekend, the Queensland Young Nationals, the young Johs and Flos of the National Party-most of whom are in their forties-called for direct subsidies to be provided for services to inland areas.

The Courier-Mail reported Mr Behan, the Young Nationals' president, as urging National Party federal parliamentarians-and that includes the Minister-to stand up and be counted on the issue, because they care about Queensland. Naturally, Mr Behan was concerned, as are we in the Opposition, about the anomaly of inland air travellers paying a 45 per cent loading above what is charged travellers on jet routes. For example, the economy fare from Brisbane to Rockhampton is $75.60, compared with a fare of $110.30 for Brisbane to Emerald, yet the distances are roughly equivalent. Mr Behan said that it was imperative that National Party parliamentarians adopt an aggressive stance, not a regressive stance, on the issue. The Queensland Minister for Transport, who is a Liberal, has given the Federal Government this warning:
If the Federal Government's decision to make TAA a public company gave TAA an open ticket to operate only on profitable routes, Queensland would fight.
If the Prime Minister knows nothing else, he should know what sort of fight Queenslanders are capable of. The Leader of the Opposition in Queensland, Mr Casey, had this to say:
We will not stand aside while TAA sacrifices people on western and northern routes on the altar of profitability.

Those are the views of representatives of the three political parties in Queensland, and they are unanimous. The Minister for Transport will be biting off more than he can chew if he pursues this course. There is no way in which he can persuade Rupert Murdoch to fill the vacuum unless, of course, he will be prepared to amend the legislation to make the loan guarantee conditional upon the company's flying the unprofitable air corridors as well as those that are profitable. Frankly, I cannot see that happening.

I will close on another note-a plaintive appeal on behalf of the consumers, the people of Australia who have had their own airline, TAA, for so many years and who will not benefit by its being taken away. I appeal to Government members of integrity to consider that it is not mud-slinging by honourable members on this side of the chamber to say: 'Look at what has been happening in the Senate in America, with senators in that country, which this Government so often lauds, calling for an investigation because they are dissatisfied with Mr Murdoch's moves regarding this loan and regarding the purchase of the Boeings'. I ask this House and this Parliament to stand by that regard and that concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —One matter needs to be made perfectly clear. The Airlines Equipment (Loan Guarantee) Bill is substantially in the standard form of such legislation that has come before the Parliament on previous occasions but takes account of certain technical points which have been raised in recent guarantee negotiations. SPEECH.PARA: The point is that the wholly owned subsidiary of Ansett Transport Industries (Operations) Pty Ltd that will be seeking to finalise its borrowings, in the final analysis, will be subject to the Treasurer's approval of the terms and conditions of the borrowing. Once the subsidiary has completed its negotiations with the lending institutions, the Crown Solicitor and officials of the Treasury will be preparing documentation for the Treasurer. If honourable members read the Bill they will find that the Treasurer is then empowered, under this legislation, to make a determination as he thinks fit. There is nothing new in the procedures under this legislation, but it probably guarantees the proper procedures more finely than any other legislation before the Parliament.

The Treasurer will then use the best offices of the Crown Solicitor and advice from his own Department before making a decision as to whether he approves the loan. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 12 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that Adelaide's water supply and the fruit growing industries along the River Murray are gravely threatened by dangerously high salinity levels.
(2) Is the River Murray Commission incapable of providing answers to these problems and has it been ineffective; if so, is a national initiative needed.

(3) Is there a need for an Australian Institute of Freshwater Studies, similar to the Australian Institute for Marine Science, to conduct research, for the first time, into the way in which this grossly pillaged river system actually functions.

(4) Will he consider using the Commonwealth's national implied powers, which was the basis of the decision in the Australian Assistance Plan Case 1975.134 CLR 338, to establish an Institute for the purpose of carrying out research and making recommendations relating to the pressing problems which face this nation in relation to the proper management and control of Australia's valuable and scarce inland water resources.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Water Resources Council and the National Health and Medical Research Council recently recommended two benchmarks relating to salinity in drinking water; 500 parts per million (ppm) as a long-term objective for drinking water of excellent quality and 1,500 ppm as the maximum level for water of satisfactory quality. Figures published by the River Murray Commission indicate that average weekly salinity levels in the River Murray at Mannum, where water is diverted for Adelaide's water supplies, have varied between 552 ppm and 630 ppm from the beginning of 1981 to the end of March. As most River Murray water for Adelaide's water supplies is blended with water from other sources, generally of lower salinity content, the salinity level in water supplied in Adelaide is lower than the River Murray recordings referred to above. The blend varies according to seasonal conditions; it is now about 40 per cent to 50 per cent River Murray water, depending on the location of the Adelaide reservoirs, and I have been informed that the current average level of salinity in Adelaide's water supplies is about 460 ppm. While salinity in the River Murray is a cause for concern, the salinity content in Adelaide's water supplies is well within the safety limits indicated in the benchmarks referred to above.

In relation to salinity in irrigation water, a 1974 publication of the Australian Water Resources Council provided benchmarks for the tolerance of various crops. These were based on information from research work in the US which indicates that most orchard crops of the kind grown in the Murray Valley tolerate salinity in irrigation water of up to an average for the growing season of about 700 ppm before crop yields decrease. A yield decrement of up to 10 per cent can be expected between this level and 1,100 ppm, and so on. Grapes are more tolerant to salinity in irrigation water than the other orchard crops. The River Murray Commission's water quality monitoring network indicates that weekly average salinity levels at points where water is diverted for most of the orchard crops in South Australia ranged from a minimum of 360 ppm at Berri to 564 ppm at Waikerie since the beginning of 1981. Salinity levels in irrigation water used for orchard crops in New South Wales and Victoria are lower than those current in South Australia. In adapting the US benchmarks to Australian conditions, adjustments would be necessary for a number of local characteristics, including soil permeability, seasonal conditions, farm management skills and irrigation practices. All factors considered in the current severe drought, it would seem that some yield decrement might be experienced this year in orchard crops in South Australia, but not of the magnitude implied in the question by the Member for Hawker.

(2) In relation to water quality, the River Murray Commission has only been given responsibilities comparatively recently on an interim basis, pending the completion of a new River Murray Waters Agreement. During this time, it has set in train action to provide basic data on which to base future considerations and operations in this area. For example, it has established a water quality monitoring network on the River Murray and it has completed a feasibility study on the development of a mathematical computer model to determine the effects of various management strategies on water quality in South Australia. The proposed River Murray Waters Agreement will provide a firm basis for the Commission in taking account of water quality issues in its operations. One will only be able to judge the effectiveness of the Commission in dealing with salinity and other water quality problems in the river after the new Agreement has been in operation for some time. In the meantime, I do not believe that a national initiative is necessary.
(3) and (4) See answer to Question No. 820, House of Representatives Hansard, page 1332.
